title.narrative: Decision on Contribution Support to GURT CSO
55070100 Decision on Contribution 2016-11-01 GURT Core Support 2016-2020.pdf (1MB)
Grant Agreement Support to GURT CSO

description.narrative: Being an innovative accelerator of societal transformations, GURT Resource Center has been delivering on its mission and vision throughout the years, including during 2019 by being an effective implementing agency of innovative projects and serving reform actors in order to develop their capacity and maximize their impact. All this fits the organization’s vision, striving for conscious and successful Ukraine where civil society, business, and government collaboratively ensure dignity, confidence, and trust among citizens at local and national levels. Within the organization’s strategic priorities – i) strengthening the foundation for civil society; ii) making civil society voice sound in the re-forming Ukraine, and iii) developing local communities, GURT was able to accomplish the following: - The constituency of GURT web-portal has remained the largest information and communication network of CSO managers and community leaders, consisting of 49,300 registered users from all oblasts of Ukraine. GURT’s Facebook page has reached 30,800 followers and continued to remain the largest information platform for civil society and community leaders in the Ukrainian segment of Facebook. GURT web-portal pages were viewed more than 5,800,000 times. GURT has been facilitating the establishment of the National CSO Network in Ukraine. In 2019, this process was taken to a new level. As a result, more than 720 CSOs joined the Memorandum on the process of Ukrainian CSO Network creation. - GURT has been promoting volunteering through supporting volunteer initiatives and making their voice sound. As a result, 370 articles dedicated to the opportunities for Ukrainian volunteers were published at the GURT web-portal in 2019. - GURT has become an official information partner for more than 50 socially useful initiatives. - Co-funded by Sweden, Opinion festivals aimed at improving civil society engagement in building a common agenda of local development with different social actors (local authorities, entrepreneurs, and non-profit organizations) and contributing to the innovative and open public multi-sectoral dialogue. The locals' interest was large enough – more than 2500 participants took part in the discussions within opinion festivals in 2019. As stated by Mr. Mykola Kychynskyi, Directorate of Professional Education of Ministry of Education, the example below demonstrates how key actors from different sectors are working together to achieve effective results: - The multi-stakeholder working group, which included representatives of the sanitary industry-leading companies, Ministry of Education and Science of Ukraine, State Employment Service of Ukraine, VET schools, and GURT Resource Center, was formed. As a result of coordinated work, the professional standard on the profession of a plumber was approved in October 2019.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

description.narrative:
Omprogrammerade medel för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 UNFPA har utarbetat ett projektförslag som bidrar till deras landprogram. Projektet har som mål att bidra till att grundläggande förutsättningar skapas för att befolkningen ska kunna utkräva sina sexuella och reproduktiva rättigheter och rätten till ett liv utan våld. Projektet ska genomföras på nationell-, distrikts- och kommunal nivå under perioden 2017 - 2020 och har en budget på 60 MSEK. Det är planerat att genomföras i 14 kommuner i fyra distrikt, nämligen: Chuquisaca, Potosí, Cochabamba and Pando. Insatsen definierar fyra resultat:
- Offentliga policies avseende SRHR och frihet från könsbaserat våld implementeras. - Förbättrad service av hög kvalitet gällande SRHR och könsbaserat våld samt stärkt sexualundervisning implementeras. - Kvinnogrupper, ursprungsfolksgrupper och andra civilsamhällsorganisationer utövar social kontroll gällande SRHR. - Befolkningen utkräver skydd av sina sexuella och reproduktiva rättigheter och hälsa.
Detta ska åstadkommas genom policydialog, påverkansarbete, framtagande av kunskap, kompetenshöjning och stärkande av institutioner. UNFPA kommer att samarbeta med relevanta ministerier och andra institutioner på nationell nivå samt relevanta myndigheter på distrikts- och kommunal nivå. Civilsamhällets organisationer kommer också att vara en samarbetspart.
Reprogrammed funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 Sexual Reproductive Health Rights

The programme shall contribute to UNFPA´s country programme in Bolivia. Specifically the program´s objective is that the population has and relies on public policies, services and knowledge that makes it possible for them to exercise their sexual and reproductive rights and the right to a life free of violence.

tag.narrative: 3.7 - By 2030, ensure universal access to sexual and reproductive health-care services, including for family planning, information and education, and the integration of reproductive health into national strategies and programmes.

3.7 - Senast 2030 säkerställa att alla har tillgång till sexuell och reproduktiv hälsovård, inklusive familjeplanering, information och utbildning, och att reproduktiv hälsa integreras i nationella strategier och program.
5.2 - Avskaffa alla former av våld mot alla kvinnor och flickor i det offentliga och privata rummet, inklusive människohandel, sexuellt utnyttjande och andra typer av exploatering.
5.2 - Eliminate all forms of violence against all women and girls in the public and private spheres, including trafficking and sexual and other types of exploitation.

5.6 - Ensure universal access to sexual and reproductive health and reproductive rights as agreed in accordance with the Programme of Action of the International Conference on Population and Development and the Beijing Platform for Action and the outcome documents of their review conferences.

5.6 - Säkerställa allmän tillgång till sexuell och reproduktiv hälsa och reproduktiva rättigheter i enlighet med överenskommelserna i handlingsprogrammet från den internationella konferensen om befolkning och utveckling, Pekingplattformen samt slutdokumenten från respektive översynskonferenser.

Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Adaptation
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Mitigation
Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn and Child Health (RMNCH)

description.narrative: The results during 2019 are: Support to comprehensive differentiated and qualified Services for SRHR, Maternity Health Services and Gender Base Violence Services: - In 16 municipalities in the country 39 young counsels have been trained in SRHR Rigths. - 39 Municipalities have been strengthening in SRHR Rigths. - Public health, justice and education servers with strengthened capacities in integral SRHR care, adolescent pregnancy prevention, prevention and care, and punishment of gender-based violence with focus on gender, generational and intercultural approaches. Health care protocols and norms developed and implemented to improve sexual and reproductive health care practices: - New norms and protocols have been approved by the government and local municipalities. - Increased capacity within local municipalities and health systems at local level to carry out procedures aimed at improving the quality of care in public health services emphasizing maternal health, family planning, adolescents and youth as well as sexual gender based violence and HIV. Program for Prevention of Pregnancy: - Youth and adolescents Program against pregnancy have been approved at department level. Local civil society working with human rigths has been strengthening in LGBT, SRHR and indigenous peoples rigths in order to follow up the CEDAW recomendations: - Social organizations of women, adolescents, youth and indigenous people demanding their rigths and carring out social control the comunities and municipalities involved. Information system for SRHR: The creation of a tracking and information platform at municipalities in order to increase the capacity of the municipalities to monitor and follow up SRHR (39 municipalities have increased their capacity).
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

title.narrative: SKR - Hållbart lokalt självstyre i en postkonliktsituation

description.narrative:
Colombia står inför ett kritiskt moment i sin historia, med en verklig möjlighet att avsluta en 50-årig intern väpnad konflikt med den största gerillarörelsen FARC-EP. Detta innebär stora möjligheter och utmaningar för att stärka och att förändra rollen för det lokala självstyret i landet. Denna process måste inledas snabbt och medföra tydliga och klara förändringar efter det att ett fredsavtal har undertecknats, annars kommer förutsättningarna att kunna genomföra ett effektivt fredsbygge på lokal nivå att försvåras år från år.
Lokala myndigheter spelar en viktig roll i fredsbyggnadsprocessen. De har en stark påverkan på fred- och konfliktssituationen på grund av deras närhet, legitimitet och konstanta närvaro i territorierna. I Colombia refererar de föreslagna fredsavtalen till "territoriell fred" (Paz Territorial), viket innebär att fredsprocessen måste anpassas efter och implementeras på lokal nivå. Kapaciteten hos de lokala myndigheterna att genomföra detta varierar mycket och det är därför viktigt att stärka denna kapacitet där det behövs. Viktiga prioriteringar som kommer att inkluderas i det här aktuella projektet, kommer att vara 1) allmänhetens deltagande, 2) system för finansiella transfereringar mellan myndigheter, samt 3) metoder för att utveckla lokala myndigheters resultatindikatorer. Jämställdhet samt miljö och klimat är centrala områden i det föreslagna samarbetet. Bl.a. väntas ingå tillhandahållande av offentliga tjänster för kvinnor och män, inklusive vatten och sanitet samt avfallshantering.
Allmänhetens deltagande: Det finns behov av att genomföra en verklig förändring vad gäller kvinnors och mäns deltagande i politiska processer, från dagens förhållande där denna till stor del sker formalistiskt utan verklig effekt, till en situation där denna sker på ett effektivt och verkningsfullt sätt. Svenska erfarenheter inom området kan bidra som inspiration för denna förändring gentemot ett mer inkluderande förhållningssätt för deltagande och social dialog. SKL har stött kommuner, landsting och regioner i Sverige för att utveckla en medborgerlig dialog, samarbeta med civilsamhället samt skapa öppenhet och transparens. Detta inkluderar utveckling av metoder för strategier för deltagande i potentiellt kontroversiella situationer och sätt att engagera politiska ledare för att främja allmänhetens deltagande.
Nationella riktlinjer för territoriell styrning, inklusive finansiering och prestandamätning: Utifrån ett postkonfliktperspektiv är det nödvändigt att öka de finansiella resurserna för svagare och konfliktdrabbade kommuner. Den huvudsakliga finansieringen i Colombia är det generella systemet för statliga bidrag till lokala och regionala enheter (Sistema General de Participaciones, SPG). Transfers genom detta system är till stor del öronmärkta för särskilda ändamål, vilket hindrar de svagare kommunerna att förbättra andra behov. De verkar dessutom hämmande för genuint deltagande eftersom kommunerna inte kan påverka hur resurserna används. DNP tittar för närvarande på formler för hur omdistribution av medlen kan förändras. I detta sammanhang måste också frågor avseende de stora skillnaderna vad gäller generering av egna inkomster mellan colombianska kommuner, omfördelning av royalties samt en föreslagen fond för postkonfliktstöd. Varje försök till förändring av systemet måste också se till att försöka öka de sammantagna inkomsterna som skall fördelas.
Det föreslagna svenska stödet syftar till att förbättra förutsättningarna för fred och hållbar utveckling i Colombia genom ökat deltagande av kvinnor och män, ansvarsutkrävande, miljömässig hållbarhet och jämlikhet i landet. Projektet kommer till stor del att fokusera på DNP och nationella riktlinjer, där svenska och internationella exempel och best practice kan hjälpa till för att förbättra utvecklingen av dessa. Det nationella arbetet kommer att kompletteras genom lokalt arbete i ett antal pilotkommuner. På denna nivå syftar projektet till att skapa nya synsätt och vägar för att jobba med deltagande, liksom resultatindikatorer.
Skydd av miljö samt klimatförändringar är viktiga frågor som ingår i processen för lokal fredsbyggnad och anpassning till en postkonfliktsituation. Kvinnor och män måste inkluderas i dialog, olika grupper behöver föras samman kring grundläggande tjänster såsom vatten, sanitet och avfallshantering, som kan leda till förbättringar hur resurser hanteras och deras påverkan på miljön. Utöver att inkludera dessa frågor i den demokratiska deltagandeprocessen, ingår aspekter kring bedömning, övervakning och planering för utvecklingen och användandet av naturresurser, och att inkludera finansiella resurser för att hantera dessa inom ramen för de kommunala budgeterna.
Miljöskydd, användning av naturresurser och de utmaningar som klimatförändringarna medför har högsta prioritet för den colombianska regeringen inom ramen för den nationella planeringen. Landet prioriterar för närvarande stärkande av miljölagar, genomförandet av dessa och utveckling av institutioner med hänsyn till deras betydelse för postkonflikten. DNPs prioriteringar för 2016 fokuserar på reformer relaterade till ett kommande medlemskap i OECD reformer (miljö- och hållbarhetsfrågor), stärkande av medborgarnas delaktighet och lokala territoriella planer. För att uppfylla målen för hållbar utveckling (SDG) kommer det att vara avgörande att säkerställa en förbättring av miljömässig hållbarhet på lokal nivå.
SKL har föreslagit en femårig insats med två huvudresultat och fyra outcomes:
1. Deltagande. Framför allt utveckling av replikerbara modeller för genuint deltagande och inkludering inom specifika sektorer och processer på lokal nivå.
Outcome 1A: Kommuner utvecklar och genomför inkluderande sätt att arbeta som kan replikeras på andra områden. Outcome 1B: DNPs riktlinjer anpassade till lokala verkligheter och internationell erfarenhet avseende deltagande och inkludering.
2. Nationella riktlinjer för territoriell finansiering och styrning. Detta innefattar utveckling av colombianska system för territoriell finansiering och ett jämlikt, hållbart och evidensbaserat system för att utvärdera territoriell styrning.
Outcome 2A: Nationella riktlinjer för territoriell styrning är influerade av lokala verkligheter och internationell erfarenhet avseende jämlika och evidensbaserade riktlinjer. Outcome 2B: DNP har kapacitet att utveckla och implementera effektiva mätinstrument för prestanda.
Projektförslaget från SKL omfattar fem år. Eftersom det för närvarande är sista året för nuvarande samarbetsstrategi för Colombia och en ny strategi är ännu inte beslutad, har ambassaden inte möjlighet att fatta beslut om ett femårigt stöd. Mot denna bakgrund föreslås beslutet att göras på tre år för perioden 2016-2018 med en möjlighet till förlängning för ytterligare två år 2019-2020. Detta passar också bra mot bakgrund av att en Mid Term Review planeras genomföras under 2018, vilken kan leda till förändringar av programmet. Enligt DNP är 2018 också lämpligt som avstämning mot bakgrund att val kommer att ske och en ny regering kommer att tillträda. Under 2019 kommer också lokalval att genomföras. Själva beredningen omfattar emellertid hela projekttiden, dvs. fem år.

Local authorities play an important role in the peace building process. They have a strong impact on peace and conflict situation due to their proximity, legitimacy and constant presence in the territories. In Colombia, the proposed peace agreements refer to "territorial peace" (Paz Territorial) which means that the peace process must be adapted to and implemented at the local level. The capacities of local authorities to implement this varies to a great extent and it is therefore important to strengthen their capacity where needed. Key priorities to included in the present project will be: 1) public participation, 2) improving systems of financial transfers between the authorities, and 3) methods to develop the local authorities' performance indicators. Key issues included in each of these priority areas is gender equality as well as environment and climate change, for example regarding the provision of public services including water and sanitation and waste management.Public participation: There is a need to implement a real change in terms of public participation of women and men in political processes, from the current situation where this is done in a more formalistic manner without any real participation, to a situation where it is done in an efficient and effective manner. Swedish experience in the field can contribute as inspiration for this change towards a more inclusive approach to participation and social dialogue. SKL has supported municipalities, county councils and regions in Sweden to develop a civic dialogue, cooperation with civil society and to create openness and transparency. This includes the development of methods for strategies for participation in potentially controversial situations and ways to involve political leaders to promote public participation.National guidelines for territorial control, including financial and performance measurement: From a post-conflict perspective, it is necessary to increase the financial resources for the weaker and conflict-affected municipalities. The primary financing in Colombia is the general system of state subsidies to local and regional units (Sistema General de Participaciones, SGP). Transfers through this system are largely earmarked for specific purposes, which prevents the weaker municipalities to improve other needs. Additionally they disencourage genuine participation because municipalities cannot influence how resources are to be used. DNP is currently looking at the formulas for how the redistribution of funds can be altered. In this context the large differences in generation of own income between Colombian municipalities, redistribution of royalties as well as a proposed fund for post-conflict support, must also be taken into account. Any reform intended to bring more resources to the municipalities where the needs are the largest would also strongly benefit from a formula that leads to a real growth of the total amount to be distributed.The proposed Swedish contribution is designed to improve the conditions for peace and sustainable development in Colombia through increased participation for women and men and accountability, environmental sustainability and gender equality in the country. The project will largely focus on the DNP and national guidelines, where Swedish and international examples and best practices can help to improve their development. The main work will be complemented by local efforts in a number of pilot municipalities. At this level, the project aims to create new approaches and ways to work with the participation, as well as performance indicators.

The overall development objective is to improve the prospects for peace and sustainable development in Colombia through greater inclusion, accountability and equity at the local level. This overall objective has not changed. From 2016 to 2019 SALAR/SKR worked in three areas of intervention: public participation, conflict management and sub-national performance and statistics information (territorial management. In 2019 inter-municipal cooperation was added as a priority in an effort to strengthen other institutional bodies that are not only the national or local level. In this sense, the project has gone from focusing to a large degree on strengthening Colombia’s National Planning Department’s (DNP) capacities to draft and develop national policies that focus on the municipalities’ needs and realities to increase the support to the local governments, their ability to organise themselves and their joint service delivery trough inter-municipal cooperation. The project’s support to national policy work has from the start been complemented by on-the-ground interventions in pilot municipalities. The extension of one more year (2021) and extra funding are proposed in response to the current Covid 19 context. On one hand, there is a need to have extra time to end the planned activities that have been delayed; on the other hand, the response to the pandemic establishes new challenges that need to be addressed, such as new digital innovative resources and tools. Also, the current context has raised problematics that are necessary to tackle in the areas of intervention such as response to gender violence - that has increased since the confinement - and adequate reactivation of the economic, social and environmental development at national and sub-national level.

sector.narrative: Decentralisation and support to subnational government

policy-marker.narrative: Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention on Biological Diversity
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention to Combat Desertification
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Adaptation
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Mitigation
Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn and Child Health (RMNCH)

description.narrative: The project has achieved many evidenced outputs as a result of well-planned and realised activities. Component 1 "Participation" has had a clear purpose all along and it has worked with a process oriented approach to citizens participation, focusing on methods and capacity building, training of trainers and implementation where the local government administration gets strengthened and can coordinate and lead new processes of participation. The project has worked with a pedagogical approach where the first step was to build capacity within the local administration with training, workshops and study visits. The main result for this component was the formulation of four "Foincide Plans", one for each municipality, collectively formulated together with participants from the community. These plans are: The Plans were all integrated into a local policy or institutional framework in the municipality and all activities were quite gender balanced. Gender was an important issue that was raised with the municipalities and the tools and methods transferred to the municipalities included strategies to include women in the participatory processes. The main results of these plans were: 1) The change in attitudes of local governments regarding citizens participation processes, 2) Increased local competence in conflict management and in planning of citizen dialogues within complex social situations and 3) Strengthened capacity at DNP. For Component 2 "Development and implementation of performance indicators", the main result was the strengthening of a data web based platform named "TerriData" and its subsequent application for smart phones. TerriData was selected as the Colombian government’s official platform for regional statistics. A mid-term review (MRT) was implemented at the end of 2018 and findings, recommendations and reflexions of the MTR were included in the 2018 report as well as in the project activities that are to be carried out for the next two years. The external evaluator considered that both outputs and outcomes have been delivered according to the projects plan and result matrix.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

In this sense, the project has gone from focusing to a large degree on strengthening Colombia’s National Planning Department’s (DNP) capacities to draft and develop national policies that focus on the municipalities’ needs and realities to increase the support to the local governments, their ability to organise themselves and their joint service delivery trough inter-municipal cooperation. The project’s support to national policy work has from the start been complemented by on-the-ground interventions in pilot municipalities. The extension of one more year (2021) and extra funding are proposed in response to the current Covid 19 context. On one hand, there is a need to have extra time to end the planned activities that have been delayed; on the other hand, the response to the pandemic establishes new challenges that need to be addressed, such as new digital innovative resources and tools. Also, the current context has raised problematics that are necessary to tackle in the areas of intervention such as response to gender violence - that has increased since the confinement - and adequate reactivation of the economic, social and environmental development at national and sub-national level.

description.narrative: The project has achieved many evidenced outputs as a result of well-planned and realised activities. Component 1 "Participation" has had a clear purpose all along and it has worked with a process oriented approach to citizens participation, focusing on methods and capacity building, training of trainers and implementation where the local government administration gets strengthened and can coordinate and lead new processes of participation. The project has worked with a pedagogical approach where the first step was to build capacity within the local administration with training, workshops and study visits. The main result for this component was the formulation of four "Foincide Plans", one for each municipality, collectively formulated together with participants from the community. These plans are: The Plans were all integrated into a local policy or institutional framework in the municipality and all activities were quite gender balanced. Gender was an important issue that was raised with the municipalities and the tools and methods transferred to the municipalities included strategies to include women in the participatory processes. The main results of these plans were: 1) The change in attitudes of local governments regarding citizens participation processes, 2) Increased local competence in conflict management and in planning of citizen dialogues within complex social situations and 3) Strengthened capacity at DNP. For Component 2 "Development and implementation of performance indicators", the main result was the strengthening of a data web based platform named "TerriData" and its subsequent application for smart phones. TerriData was selected as the Colombian government’s official platform for regional statistics. A mid-term review (MRT) was implemented at the end of 2018 and findings, recommendations and reflexions of the MTR were included in the 2018 report as well as in the project activities that are to be carried out for the next two years. The external evaluator considered that both outputs and outcomes have been delivered according to the projects plan and result matrix.

sida:strategy.sida:title: Colombia 2016-2020
sida:strategy.sida:titleSV: Colombia 2016-2020

title.narrative: SKR - Hållbart lokalt självstyre i en postkonliktsituation

description.narrative:
Colombia står inför ett kritiskt moment i sin historia, med en verklig möjlighet att avsluta en 50-årig intern väpnad konflikt med den största gerillarörelsen FARC-EP. Detta innebär stora möjligheter och utmaningar för att stärka och att förändra rollen för det lokala självstyret i landet. Denna process måste inledas snabbt och medföra tydliga och klara förändringar efter det att ett fredsavtal har undertecknats, annars kommer förutsättningarna att kunna genomföra ett effektivt fredsbygge på lokal nivå att försvåras år från år.
Lokala myndigheter spelar en viktig roll i fredsbyggnadsprocessen. De har en stark påverkan på fred- och konfliktssituationen på grund av deras närhet, legitimitet och konstanta närvaro i territorierna. I Colombia refererar de föreslagna fredsavtalen till "territoriell fred" (Paz Territorial), viket innebär att fredsprocessen måste anpassas efter och implementeras på lokal nivå. Kapaciteten hos de lokala myndigheterna att genomföra detta varierar mycket och det är därför viktigt att stärka denna kapacitet där det behövs. Viktiga prioriteringar som kommer att inkluderas i det här aktuella projektet, kommer att vara 1) allmänhetens deltagande, 2) system för finansiella transfereringar mellan myndigheter, samt 3) metoder för att utveckla lokala myndigheters resultatindikatorer. Jämställdhet samt miljö och klimat är centrala områden i det föreslagna samarbetet. Bl.a. väntas ingå tillhandahållande av offentliga tjänster för kvinnor och män, inklusive vatten och sanitet samt avfallshantering.
Allmänhetens deltagande: Det finns behov av att genomföra en verklig förändring vad gäller kvinnors och mäns deltagande i politiska processer, från dagens förhållande där denna till stor del sker formalistiskt utan verklig effekt, till en situation där denna sker på ett effektivt och verkningsfullt sätt. Svenska erfarenheter inom området kan bidra som inspiration för denna förändring gentemot ett mer inkluderande förhållningssätt för deltagande och social dialog. SKL har stött kommuner, landsting och regioner i Sverige för att utveckla en medborgerlig dialog, samarbeta med civilsamhället samt skapa öppenhet och transparens. Detta inkluderar utveckling av metoder för strategier för deltagande i potentiellt kontroversiella situationer och sätt att engagera politiska ledare för att främja allmänhetens deltagande.
Nationella riktlinjer för territoriell styrning, inklusive finansiering och prestandamätning: Utifrån ett postkonfliktperspektiv är det nödvändigt att öka de finansiella resurserna för svagare och konfliktdrabbade kommuner. Den huvudsakliga finansieringen i Colombia är det generella systemet för statliga bidrag till lokala och regionala enheter (Sistema General de Participaciones, SPG). Transfers genom detta system är till stor del öronmärkta för särskilda ändamål, vilket hindrar de svagare kommunerna att förbättra andra behov. De verkar dessutom hämmande för genuint deltagande eftersom kommunerna inte kan påverka hur resurserna används. DNP tittar för närvarande på formler för hur omdistribution av medlen kan förändras. I detta sammanhang måste också frågor avseende de stora skillnaderna vad gäller generering av egna inkomster mellan colombianska kommuner, omfördelning av royalties samt en föreslagen fond för postkonfliktstöd. Varje försök till förändring av systemet måste också se till att försöka öka de sammantagna inkomsterna som skall fördelas.
Det föreslagna svenska stödet syftar till att förbättra förutsättningarna för fred och hållbar utveckling i Colombia genom ökat deltagande av kvinnor och män, ansvarsutkrävande, miljömässig hållbarhet och jämlikhet i landet. Projektet kommer till stor del att fokusera på DNP och nationella riktlinjer, där svenska och internationella exempel och best practice kan hjälpa till för att förbättra utvecklingen av dessa. Det nationella arbetet kommer att kompletteras genom lokalt arbete i ett antal pilotkommuner. På denna nivå syftar projektet till att skapa nya synsätt och vägar för att jobba med deltagande, liksom resultatindikatorer.
Skydd av miljö samt klimatförändringar är viktiga frågor som ingår i processen för lokal fredsbyggnad och anpassning till en postkonfliktsituation. Kvinnor och män måste inkluderas i dialog, olika grupper behöver föras samman kring grundläggande tjänster såsom vatten, sanitet och avfallshantering, som kan leda till förbättringar hur resurser hanteras och deras påverkan på miljön. Utöver att inkludera dessa frågor i den demokratiska deltagandeprocessen, ingår aspekter kring bedömning, övervakning och planering för utvecklingen och användandet av naturresurser, och att inkludera finansiella resurser för att hantera dessa inom ramen för de kommunala budgeterna.
Miljöskydd, användning av naturresurser och de utmaningar som klimatförändringarna medför har högsta prioritet för den colombianska regeringen inom ramen för den nationella planeringen. Landet prioriterar för närvarande stärkande av miljölagar, genomförandet av dessa och utveckling av institutioner med hänsyn till deras betydelse för postkonflikten. DNPs prioriteringar för 2016 fokuserar på reformer relaterade till ett kommande medlemskap i OECD reformer (miljö- och hållbarhetsfrågor), stärkande av medborgarnas delaktighet och lokala territoriella planer. För att uppfylla målen för hållbar utveckling (SDG) kommer det att vara avgörande att säkerställa en förbättring av miljömässig hållbarhet på lokal nivå.
SKL har föreslagit en femårig insats med två huvudresultat och fyra outcomes:
1. Deltagande. Framför allt utveckling av replikerbara modeller för genuint deltagande och inkludering inom specifika sektorer och processer på lokal nivå.
Outcome 1A: Kommuner utvecklar och genomför inkluderande sätt att arbeta som kan replikeras på andra områden. Outcome 1B: DNPs riktlinjer anpassade till lokala verkligheter och internationell erfarenhet avseende deltagande och inkludering.
2. Nationella riktlinjer för territoriell finansiering och styrning. Detta innefattar utveckling av colombianska system för territoriell finansiering och ett jämlikt, hållbart och evidensbaserat system för att utvärdera territoriell styrning.
Outcome 2A: Nationella riktlinjer för territoriell styrning är influerade av lokala verkligheter och internationell erfarenhet avseende jämlika och evidensbaserade riktlinjer. Outcome 2B: DNP har kapacitet att utveckla och implementera effektiva mätinstrument för prestanda.
Projektförslaget från SKL omfattar fem år. Eftersom det för närvarande är sista året för nuvarande samarbetsstrategi för Colombia och en ny strategi är ännu inte beslutad, har ambassaden inte möjlighet att fatta beslut om ett femårigt stöd. Mot denna bakgrund föreslås beslutet att göras på tre år för perioden 2016-2018 med en möjlighet till förlängning för ytterligare två år 2019-2020. Detta passar också bra mot bakgrund av att en Mid Term Review planeras genomföras under 2018, vilken kan leda till förändringar av programmet. Enligt DNP är 2018 också lämpligt som avstämning mot bakgrund att val kommer att ske och en ny regering kommer att tillträda. Under 2019 kommer också lokalval att genomföras. Själva beredningen omfattar emellertid hela projekttiden, dvs. fem år.

Local authorities play an important role in the peace building process. They have a strong impact on peace and conflict situation due to their proximity, legitimacy and constant presence in the territories. In Colombia, the proposed peace agreements refer to "territorial peace" (Paz Territorial) which means that the peace process must be adapted to and implemented at the local level. The capacities of local authorities to implement this varies to a great extent and it is therefore important to strengthen their capacity where needed. Key priorities to included in the present project will be: 1) public participation, 2) improving systems of financial transfers between the authorities, and 3) methods to develop the local authorities' performance indicators. Key issues included in each of these priority areas is gender equality as well as environment and climate change, for example regarding the provision of public services including water and sanitation and waste management.Public participation: There is a need to implement a real change in terms of public participation of women and men in political processes, from the current situation where this is done in a more formalistic manner without any real participation, to a situation where it is done in an efficient and effective manner. Swedish experience in the field can contribute as inspiration for this change towards a more inclusive approach to participation and social dialogue. SKL has supported municipalities, county councils and regions in Sweden to develop a civic dialogue, cooperation with civil society and to create openness and transparency. This includes the development of methods for strategies for participation in potentially controversial situations and ways to involve political leaders to promote public participation.National guidelines for territorial control, including financial and performance measurement: From a post-conflict perspective, it is necessary to increase the financial resources for the weaker and conflict-affected municipalities. The primary financing in Colombia is the general system of state subsidies to local and regional units (Sistema General de Participaciones, SGP). Transfers through this system are largely earmarked for specific purposes, which prevents the weaker municipalities to improve other needs. Additionally they disencourage genuine participation because municipalities cannot influence how resources are to be used. DNP is currently looking at the formulas for how the redistribution of funds can be altered. In this context the large differences in generation of own income between Colombian municipalities, redistribution of royalties as well as a proposed fund for post-conflict support, must also be taken into account. Any reform intended to bring more resources to the municipalities where the needs are the largest would also strongly benefit from a formula that leads to a real growth of the total amount to be distributed.The proposed Swedish contribution is designed to improve the conditions for peace and sustainable development in Colombia through increased participation for women and men and accountability, environmental sustainability and gender equality in the country. The project will largely focus on the DNP and national guidelines, where Swedish and international examples and best practices can help to improve their development. The main work will be complemented by local efforts in a number of pilot municipalities. At this level, the project aims to create new approaches and ways to work with the participation, as well as performance indicators.

The overall development objective is to improve the prospects for peace and sustainable development in Colombia through greater inclusion, accountability and equity at the local level. This overall objective has not changed. From 2016 to 2019 SALAR/SKR worked in three areas of intervention: public participation, conflict management and sub-national performance and statistics information (territorial management. In 2019 inter-municipal cooperation was added as a priority in an effort to strengthen other institutional bodies that are not only the national or local level. In this sense, the project has gone from focusing to a large degree on strengthening Colombia’s National Planning Department’s (DNP) capacities to draft and develop national policies that focus on the municipalities’ needs and realities to increase the support to the local governments, their ability to organise themselves and their joint service delivery trough inter-municipal cooperation. The project’s support to national policy work has from the start been complemented by on-the-ground interventions in pilot municipalities. The extension of one more year (2021) and extra funding are proposed in response to the current Covid 19 context. On one hand, there is a need to have extra time to end the planned activities that have been delayed; on the other hand, the response to the pandemic establishes new challenges that need to be addressed, such as new digital innovative resources and tools. Also, the current context has raised problematics that are necessary to tackle in the areas of intervention such as response to gender violence - that has increased since the confinement - and adequate reactivation of the economic, social and environmental development at national and sub-national level.

Omprogrammerade medel för att bekämpa covid-19 Sida's bidrag till FN:s fredsfond för Colombia. Fonden ger bidrag till insatser för stabilisering förtroendeskapande samt genomförandet av fredsavtalet mellan den colombianska regeringen och FARC, i syfte att: 1. Öka lokalbefolkningens förtroende för statliga institutioner på nationell och lokal nivå. 2. Öka människors och i synnerhet offren och / medborgares förtroende för fredsprocessen i de områden som drabbats hårdast av konflikten. 3. Förhindra och/eller minska brott och våld i samband med utbrott av väpnade konflikter och demobiliseringsprocesser. 4. Hantera konfliktsituationer på lokal nivå genom tidiga insatser (rapid response). 5. Bidra till att skapa fredsvinster, konkreta positiva förbättringar för människors dagliga liv, inom områdena säkerhet, rättvisa och utveckling. Andra givare till fonden inkluderar Canada, Irland, Norge, Storbritannien, Tyskland, och Schweiz.

Reprogrammed funds to address COVID-19 Sida's contribution to the UN multi-partner trust fund for Colombia. The fund supports actions for stabilization, building trust and implementation of the Peace Accords between the colombian government and FARC, aiming to: 1. Increase trust in public instutions among the local population; 2. Increase trust in the peace process, in particular among victims and Citizens in conflict affected areas; 3. Prevent crimes and voilence in armed conflict and demobilizationsprocesses. 4. Manage conflictivity at local level through rapid response 5. contribute to create peace gains, positive change in people's daily lives in the areas of security, justice and development. Other donors to the fund include Canada, Ireland, Norway, Great Britain, Germany and Switzerland.

tag.narrative: 16.1 - Avsevärt minska alla former av våld och dödligt våld överallt.
16.1 - Significantly reduce all forms of violence and related death rates everywhere.

title.narrative: We Effect Mayakvinnors ekonomiska egenmakt på landsbygden
We Effect Rural Mayan Women’s Economic Empowerment

description.narrative: Omprogrammerade medel för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 Utvecklingsinsatsen syftar till att minska fattigdom bland ursprungsbefolkningar i fyra territorier på landsbygden i Guatemala genom ett fokus på kvinnors ekonomiska egenmakt och förebyggande av könsbaserat våld. Totalt förväntas 7500 ekonomiska initiativ sammansatta och ledda av kvinnor få tillgång till tekniskt och finansiellt stöd, förbättrad tillgång till lokala, regionala och nationella marknader. We Effect samarbetar med tio lokala organisationer i implementeringen av projektet under åren 2016-2020.

Reprogrammed funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 This intervention aims to reduce poverty and violence on indigenous people, particularly Mayan women in four territories of Guatemala, promoting Women´s Economic Empowerment, through strengthening their capacities on productive technical matters and entrepreneurship; strengthening the peasant organizations capacities to ensure their response to their members to reduce poverty and strengthening advocacy work. The project also aims to improve market access and position of rural Mayan women within a framework of organizational strengthening and deepening knowledge of rights and demands for rights compliance, recognizing that economic empowerment ensures sustainable individual, collective and political empowerment.
The State and other actors contribute to rights holders’ poverty and violence reduction, especially for indigenous women in four rural territories of Guatemala.

tag.narrative: 1.1 - By 2030, eradicate extreme poverty for all people everywhere, currently measured as people living on less than $1.25 a day.
1.1 - Senast 2030 avskaffa den extrema fattigdomen för alla människor överallt. Med extrem fattigdom avses för närvarande människor som lever på mindre än 1,25 US-dollar per dag.
2.1 - By 2030, end hunger and ensure access by all people, in particular the poor and people in vulnerable situations, including infants, to safe, nutritious and sufficient food all year round.

2.1 - Senast 2030 avskaffa hunger och garantera alla människor, i synnerhet de fattiga och människor i utsatta situationer, inklusive små barn, tillgång till tillräckligt med säker och näringsrik mat året om.
5.1 - Avskaffa alla former av diskriminering av alla kvinnor och flickor överallt
5.1 - End all forms of discrimination against all women and girls everywhere.

description.narrative: Main achieved results: -PODEEIR project focuses on promoting women´s economic empowerment in a holistic way. The project promotes processes seeking equal rights and creates productive and economic opportunities specially for poor rural indigenous women so that they can improve their living conditions. Besides promotes gender-based violence prevention and contributes to streghthen social organization. -Women participating in the project and their organizations have become more aware that violence against women and inequalities that they face are not something natural, it is something that can be eradicated. Now women feel more empowered to claim their economic, political and social rights. Women participaton in productive activities that were previously only intended for men has been an important change. Nowadays women have their own productive enterprises and are participate in local markets with their good quality products,which gives them opportunities to increase their income and possibilities to influence on decision making within their home and community. Changes are also taking place in terms of practices and customs about relegating women to domestic sphere. - Around 67 productive enterprises created by 4,928 women in 145 rural communities contribute to increase Women income and improve the families and communities access to healthy food. The partner organizations, have created spaces for women and men participation in decision-making and access to productive assets. Women formed into groups are participating in the economic sphere, as producers, generating income, and doing business. Taking into account that in acountry like Guatemala with a lot of inequality and a very patriarchal culture, these are considered important changes. -Within the emergency measures adopted to contain the Covid-19 pandemic, access to communities was closed, which limited commercialization of products, and caused crop losses and food shortages. However, in some way, the project's target groups, having their own food production in their communities, had for self-consumption and to sell or exchange with their neighbors, so it can be said that target groups that are in a situation of vulnerability, are having a certain capacity for response and are resilient to economic crises such as those that the pandemic is causing. -It is important to mention that the counterpart not only promotes access to economic resources for the target groups, but rather, it makes a comprehensive approach to the empowerment of people with an approach based on human rights. We Effect starts from the premise that poverty is not only a lack of resources but also a lack of power. Therefore, in order to change this condition, actions such as strengthening of community organization, training, awareness, technical and financial support, have been promoted that help women have the power to influence making decisions that have to do with improving their living conditions at the family level, within their organizations and communities. Likewise, actions on gender-based violence prevention are promoted. The target groups, both men and women, have knowledge and tools about how violence against women can be prevented, the types of violence that exist and the importance of women's participation in the development of their communities. In times of the COVID-19 pandemic, violence against women has increased, so local radio campaigns on addressing violence against women have been implemented, among other actions. -To reduce the work overload that women experience, the project promotes the distribution of household chores. As a result, of 5128 women, 25% report positive changes in the distribution of tasks within their household and have more time to devote to other activities for their benefit. (This data was collected through surveys and focus groups as part of the final evaluation of the project). -As a result of financial literacy training, women are more confident in accessing loans to invest in their businesses and create savings. Likewise, they have a greater capacity to perform investment calculations and profits from their ventures. -Cultivation techniques and methods are introduced for natural resources sustainable management, such as reforestation, gray water management, elaboration of organic compost, insecticides, pesticides and foliar plants for agroecological production, among others.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

sida:strategy.sida:title: Guatemala 2016-2020
sida:strategy.sida:titleSV: Guatemala 2016-2020

title.narrative: Helvetas project inclusive economic and social development-Scaling up phase
Helvetas projekt för en inkluderande ekonomisk och social utveckling Första fas

description.narrative:
Omprogrammerade medel för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 Utvecklingsinsatsen syftar till att minska fattigdom hos landsbygdsbefolkning på västra höglandet i Guatemala genom att facilitera produktiv sysselsättning och utnyttja potential och kulturella värden i den lokala produktionen. Insatsen riktar sig särskilt till urfolkskvinnor. Totalt 26 750 familjer kommer att kunna dra nytta av tekniskt bistånd, förbättrade jordbruksmetoder, tillgång till finansiella tjänster för att utveckla sin produktiva verksamhet, samt tillgång till nationella och internationella marknader. Insatsen genomförs i samarbete med lokala företag, jordbruksorganisationer, samt med nationella och lokala myndigheter.
Helvetas ansöker om tilläggsmedel om 79 800 000 SEK för perioden 2018-2021 för att genomföra utvecklingsinsatsen. Helvetas kommer även att tillföra egna medel om 7 200 000 SEK för expanderingsfasen som startar 2018, och viss delfinansiering kommer att tillhandahållas av kommunerna.

Reprogrammed funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 PRODERT Scaling-up objective is: "Vulnerable rural population particularly indigenous women increase their income and productive employment by capitalising on the potential of local production and cultural values in five departments of the western highlands of Guatemala". The intervention seeks to achieve sustainable results over time and disseminate good practices of the current "Territorial Rural Economic Development Project" PRODERT, in order for the market systems to work more effectively and inclusively in favour of the poor, as well as to increase the number of beneficiaries with potential to increase income and participate in market systems (from 7,500 to 26,750 direct beneficiaries), and increasing geographical coverage from 16 to 27 municipalities in the Departments of Huehuetenango, San Marcos, Totonicapán, Quiché and Quetzaltenango. During this phase the project is expected to develop complementary alliances with potential market partners to support innovations in order to increase scale, scope and to strengthen the target groups response capacity, sustainability and resilience. According to Helvetas, due to the positive results of the previous phases of PRODERT, there is an imminent interest in the selected communities where the population has expressed strong interest to participate in the project. Until now, it has not been possible to incorporate them due to lack of funds.´Based on a previous MSD/M4P analysis, main identified constrains of the target groups to be part of the market systems are: (i) to reach a good level of associativity, (ii) lack of inclusive financial services (iii) lack of technical assistance and (iv) business development. In collaboration with different public, private and civil society actors the project with a catalyst role is expected to facilitate systemic changes in the identified constraints and Helvetas will focus on overcome these barriers. Preliminarily the intervention will support the development of 6 viable value chains with market potential and scaling up: potatoes, coffee, vegetables, handicrafts, beekeeping and sheep.
PRODERT Scaling up amounts SEK 79 800 000, for the period 2018 – 2021. Besides, as part of this intervention it is estimated that the Department of Loans and Guarantees at Sida Headquarter (HQ) will support a guarantee and capital risk instrument, the cost of the guarantee is not still defined. A mission from the Sida HQ visited Guatemala in October 2017 to start assessing this specific support.

tag.narrative: 1.4 - By 2030, ensure that all men and women, in particular the poor and the vulnerable, have equal rights to economic resources, as well as access to basic services, ownership and control over land and other forms of property, inheritance, natural resources, appropriate new technology and financial services, including microfinance.

1.4 - Senast 2030 säkerställa att alla män och kvinnor, i synnerhet de fattiga och de utsatta, har lika rätt till ekonomiska resurser, tillgång till grundläggande tjänster, möjlighet att äga och kontrollera mark och andra former av egendom samt tillgång till arv, naturresurser, lämplig ny teknik och finansiella tjänster, inklusive mikrokrediter.

2.3 - By 2030, double the agricultural productivity and incomes of small-scale food producers, in particular women, indigenous peoples, family farmers, pastoralists and fishers, including through secure and equal access to land, other productive resources and inputs, knowledge, financial services, markets and opportunities for value addition and non-farm employment.

2.3 - Till 2030 fördubbla jordbrukets produktivitet och inkomster för småskaliga livsmedelsproducenter, i synnerhet kvinnor, ursprungsfolk, familjejordbrukare, boskapsskötande nomader samt fiskare, inklusive genom säker och lika tillgång till mark, andra produktionsresurser och insatsvaror, kunskap, finansiella tjänster och marknader samt möjligheter till värdeskapande och sysselsättning utanför jordbruket.

5.4 - Erkänna och värdesätta obetalt omsorgs- och hushållsarbete genom att tillhandahålla offentliga tjänster, infrastruktur och socialt skydd samt genom att främja delat ansvar inom hushållet och familjen, i enlighet med vad som är nationellt lämpligt.

5.4 - Recognize and value unpaid care and domestic work through the provision of public services, infrastructure and social protection policies and the promotion of shared responsibility within the household and the family as nationally appropriate.

8.3 - Främja utvecklingsinriktad politik som stöder produktiv verksamhet, skapande av anständiga arbetstillfällen, företagande, kreativitet och innovation samt uppmuntra att mikroföretag liksom små och medelstora företag växer och blir en del av den formella ekonomin, bland annat genom tillgång till finansiella tjänster.

8.3 - Promote development-oriented policies that support productive activities, decent job creation, entrepreneurship, creativity and innovation, and encourage the formalization and growth of micro-, small- and medium-sized enterprises, including through access to financial services.

policy-marker.narrative: Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention on Biological Diversity
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention to Combat Desertification
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Adaptation
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Mitigation
Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn and Child Health (RMNCH)

description.narrative: Narrative report 2020, contains a results-based approach. Despite the different limitations and impact that the pandemic has had due to the sanitary measures and restrictions imposed by the Guatemalan State, it is important to mention that the project achieved,in comparison with the approved Operational Plan and budget 2020 a technical and financial execution of 97%. The project applies a Market systems development approach, therefore, in this phase of the project, systemic changes are already evident in the intervention. Most important changes and results: Through the development of agricultural and livestock ventures, around 40,000 producers, mostly indigenous in rural areas with 74% women, have benefited from the project by improving their income, their access to markets and as producer strengthening their organization (356 business networks). During 2020, the target groups improved their businesses, they were able to access formal markets, reaching sales goals of around 40MSEK (this data is for the entire group, there is no more specific data per producer). Also, 3,859 jobs were created. Key actors who contributed to small producers to enter markets, improve their income and access employment or self-employment. -17 anchor companies are contributing to the promotion of associativity, to adopt inclusive business models seeking gender equity, and good agricultural and livestock practices that are friendly to the environment. These companies provide technical assistance to increase productivity, financial services, training, and market opening. For this, the project has assumed a catalytic role and facilitator of these alliances through a competitive fund with private companies (like a type of challenge fund named "FIAGRO Fund". -28 Municipal governments co-invested in productive-commercial projects led by women around 5MSEK. This contribution was added to the counterpart of the beneficiaries and the project investment, achieving a greater impact on the economic reactivation of the families specially those most affected by COVID. -To promote local economic development 20 municipal governments have developed public policies, as well as promote concertation spaces and a facilitated a favorable environment for investment. -A network of 1,500 agricultural promoters has been established and trained to provide technical assistance to business networks in their communities where there is little access to technical services. -In some covered areas by the project it has contributed to the establishment of 5 agroclimatic technical tables, which are integrated by government institutions, among others, these tables generate information on weather forecasts, which is disseminated to producers to avoid crop losses due to any weather variability. -The project has promoted awareness-raising and training processes on gender equity and prevention of violence against women. Currently women recognize the types of violence and how to report them, more women occupy positions in decision-making within business networks in their communities, as well as having their own businesses and income, and have control over their income. In this phase of the project, important results have been achieved. The achieved results are in line with the objectives.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

sida:strategy.sida:title: Guatemala 2016-2020
sida:strategy.sida:titleSV: Guatemala 2016-2020

title.narrative: FAO & UNICEF stöd till familjer som drabbats av torkan i Guatemala år 2014.
FAO & UNICEF support to families affected by drought 2014 in Guatemala.

description.narrative: Dry Corridor Joint Program aims to recover the livelihoods of small-scale family farmers of subsistence and infrasubsistence affected by 2014 drought in two communities of Jalapa (San Pedro Pinula and San Luis Jilotepeque) and three of Chiquimula (Camotán, Jocotán and Chiquimula). The program provides low cost technologies for food security adapted to drought, technical assistance to manage and prepare the small-scale farmers plots to better face droughts, increase their yields to promote food security. The program works closely to families, farmers organizations and municipalities through information and training to promote integrated micro-watershed management.

Omprogrammerade medel för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 Guatemala har upplevt en förlängd period av torka under 2014, vilket har påverkan främst i de nordöstra delarna av landet och det område som kallas "den torra korridoren". Torkan har särskilt påverkat personer i fattigdom och extremfattigdom som är beroende av jordbruk för deras uppehälle. Guatemalas regering förklarade katastroftillstånd i de drabbade departementen och framförde en vädjan om humanitärt bistånd. Regeringen lanserade också en plan bistå befolkningen som drabbats. Planen omfattar tre strategier: 1) humanitärt bistånd, 2) återhämtning av försörjningsmöjligheter och 3) motståndskraft och anpassning till klimatförändringar. FN systemet i Guatemala presenterade en omgripande plan som svar på regeringens förfrågan om stöd. Detta projekt är baserat på FAO och UNICEFs föreslagna roller på medel- och långsikt i den planen. Projektet är därmed i linje med Guatemalas regeringsplan för bistånd på medellång och lång sikt: 2) återhämtning av försörjningsmöjligheter och 3) motståndskraft och anpassning till klimatförändringar. Projektansökan är för en period på två år och budgeten är på 20 MSEK. Initiativet syftar till att återställa försörjningsmöjligheter för de familjer som drabbats av den långvariga torkan under 2014, samt skapa motståndskraft hos dem genom metoder för handhålland och bevarande av jord och vatten i kommuner i regionerna Chiquimula och Jalapa.

Reprogrammed funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 Guatemala has experienced a prolonged drought during 2014 affecting the north east of the country. The drought has particularly affected smallholder farmers with subsistence and infra subsistence production in the area known as the dry corridor. The Guatemalan government declared a state of emergency in the affected departments and submitted an appeal for humanitarian aid. The government, through its Council of Nutrition and Food Security, SESAN (for its acronym in Spanish), has recognized the damages caused by the extended drought. This led to the government declaring State of Public Calamity in the departments affected and made an appeal for humanitarian assistance. The government also launched a plan to attend the population affected that includes three strategies: 1) humanitarian assistance, 2) livelihoods recovery and 3) resilience and adaptation to climate change. The United Nations system in Guatemala presented a response plan in reaction to the government's request for support. This project is based on the proposed roles for FAO and UNICEF in the medium and long term of the plan. The project is therefore in line with the Guatemalan government plan for the assistance in the medium and long term: 2) recovery of livelihoods and 3) the resilience and adaptation to climate change. The project application is for a period of two years and a budget of 20 MSEK. The contribution aims to recover the livelihoods of the families affected by prolonged drought of 2014, as well as, to create resilience through management and conservation of soil and water in Chiquimula and Jalapa.

tag.narrative: 1.5 - By 2030, build the resilience of the poor and those in vulnerable situations and reduce their exposure and vulnerability to climate-related extreme events and other economic, social and environmental shocks and disasters.

1.5 - Till 2030 bygga upp motståndskraften hos de fattiga och människor i utsatta situationer och minska deras utsatthet och sårbarhet för extrema klimatrelaterade händelser och andra ekonomiska, sociala och miljömässiga chocker och katastrofer.
13.1 - Strengthen resilience and adaptive capacity to climate-related hazards and natural disasters in all countries.
13.1 - Stärka motståndskraften mot och förmågan till anpassning till klimatrelaterade faror och naturkatastrofer i alla länder.
15.3 - By 2030, combat desertification, restore degraded land and soil, including land affected by desertification, drought and floods, and strive to achieve a land degradation-neutral world.

15.3 - Till 2030 bekämpa ökenspridning, återställa förstörd mark och jord, inklusive mark som drabbats av ökenspridning, torka och översvämningar, samt sträva efter att uppnå en värld utan nettoförstöring av mark.

2.4 - By 2030, ensure sustainable food production systems and implement resilient agricultural practices that increase productivity and production, that help maintain ecosystems, that strengthen capacity for adaptation to climate change, extreme weather, drought, flooding and other disasters and that progressively improve land and soil quality.

2.4 - Senast 2030 uppnå hållbara system för livsmedelsproduktion samt införa motståndskraftiga jordbruksmetoder som ökar produktiviteten och produktionen, som bidrar till att upprätthålla ekosystemen, som stärker förmågan till anpassning till klimatförändringar, extrema väderförhållanden, torka, översvämning och andra katastrofer och som successivt förbättrar mark- och jordkvaliteten.
5.5 - Ensure women’s full and effective participation and equal opportunities for leadership at all levels of decision-making in political, economic and public life.
5.5 - Tillförsäkra kvinnor fullt och faktiskt deltagande och lika möjligheter till ledarskap på alla beslutsnivåer i det politiska, ekonomiska och offentliga livet.
6.6 - By 2020, protect and restore water-related ecosystems, including mountains, forests, wetlands, rivers, aquifers and lakes.
6.6 - Senast 2020 skydda och återställa de vattenrelaterade ekosystemen, däribland berg, skogar, våtmarker, floder, akviferer och sjöar.
6.b - Stödja och stärka lokalsamhällenas deltagande i arbetet med att förbättra vatten- och sanitetshanteringen.
6.b - Support and strengthen the participation of local communities in improving water and sanitation management.

policy-marker.narrative: Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention on Biological Diversity
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention to Combat Desertification
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Adaptation
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Mitigation
Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn and Child Health (RMNCH)

description.narrative: Implementation during 2020 was influenced by COVID-19 pandemic and the measures taken to face the COVID-19 implications, such as changes in operations, country lock down, design and implementation of a COVID-19 response plan. The program's operations changed regarding training sessions, groups were divided in groups of 10, gel alcohol and face masks were provided to keep physical distance between participants; information about COVID-19 prevention was introduced to support the containment of the pandemic; a response plan was designed and implemented to support the most vulnerable families to go through the lock downs and the economic consequences of the pandemic. Changes at the operations gave good results allowing the program to achieve results in a pandemic context, for example: - 6,067 or 86% of families supported implemented at least 10 good agricultural practices in their homes or plots increasing their food availability, improving their natural resources management, and increasing their resilience to drought. 1. home gardens; 2. backyard bird vaccination; 3. disinfection of water for human consumption; 4. conservation community basic grain banks; 5. structures for soil conservation; 6. contingency mutual funds; 7. community tool banks; 8. Kuxur rum agroforestry system; 9. micro watershed management; 10. Rain water harvest. - 96% of participant families (6,766) implemented home gardens allowing them food availability during the pandemic, including plant-based protein. - COVID-19 pandemic response plan was implemented with 4,000 vulnerable families, which included: increased yields of vegetables in 3 months; recovery of backyard poultry and production of eggs and meat for family’s self-consumption; production of bean grains for self-consumption and commercialization 8,750 quintals were produced, allowing food reserves and sales for Q.4,375,000. - Harvesting and storing 16 million liters of rainwater through structures of rainwater harvest, the stored water is used for human consumption and household sanitation in times of COVID-19, as well as for family agricultural production and community, during the COVID-19 pandemic has been an important factor for families to produce vegetables at the family and community level. Rainwater harvest has been a good and low-cost climate change adaptation tool. - Ministry of Health and Municipalities have assumed the commitment to continue and support the process of adequate management of water for human consumption in coordination with 5 health districts, 5 municipalities, 5 micro-watershed councils and 25 water committees for water collection, distribution, chlorination and proper use of water for human consumption. - Implementation of the pilot coffee project “Linking women and young coffee growers of small scale to specialty coffee markets, in alliance with WAKAMI / Communities of the Earth, Finca El Faro / Comercializadora el Grano and OLAM. Three groups of 171 small-scale coffee growers, from of which 81 are women, from San José Poaquil, Chimaltenango, Nebaj and Chajul, Quiche have produced and commercializes 600 quintals of coffee sold in an average price per quintal of USD 122.00, the price is 25 dollars above the price of a coffee conventional. - 50 families, through 50 fishponds produced 20,000 pounds of tilapia worth. - 22 entrepreneurial groups under the Contingency Mutual Funds methodology were strengthened in accounting and administration allowing the families access to credit.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

sida:strategy.sida:title: Guatemala 2016-2020
sida:strategy.sida:titleSV: Guatemala 2016-2020

title.narrative: UNDP - Cuilco Rural Development Joint Program

description.narrative: Cuilco Program intends to provide multiple solutions to development in territories, it is focused in small-scale farmers families, farmer organizations and government institutions present in the territory (Municipalities and Ministries). The Program works with public institutions to generate evidence to facilitate right holders greater access to quality public services to improve their lives and strengthens duty bearers to perform their mandates in the territory and to better respond to the citizens demands.The program works in economic, cultural and social rights, including the right to food and the enjoyment of a safe, clean, healthy and sustainable environment. It has been implemented since November 2015 in Tejutla, Comitancillo, Concepción Tutuapa, Sipacapa and San Miguel Ixtaguacán in San Marcos, Guatemala.

Omprogrammerade medel för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 Insatsen, som leds av UNDP, bygger på det sammarbete som tre FN organen har haft under första delen av projektet "Joint Program" i San Marcos regionen. Där uppnåddes en väl fungerande interinstitutionell samordning mellan UNDP- FAO -WHO, civilsamhället, samt lokala och centrala myndigheter. denna insats bygger vidare på detta och har som målsättning att förbättra levnadsvillkoren för familjer som livnär sig på jordbruk och förbättra deras tillgång till sjukvård samt motsståndskraft mot naturkatastrofer. Denna fas 2 kommer verka i kommuner som inte inkluderades i FAS 1 nämligen Comitancillo, San Miguel Ixtahuacán, Concepción Tutuapa, Sipacapa y Tejutla i San Marcos. Initiativet kommer även att arbeta med att förbättra kapaciteten bland aktörer från civilsamhället, lokala och centrala myndigheter för att säkerställa framtagandet och implementeringen av kommunala utvecklingsplaner, samt främja deltagande i lokala utvecklingskommittéer för att främja lokala investeringar.

Reprogrammed funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 The proposal aims to replicate inter-institutional coordination between UN Agencies, civil society, local and central government to reproduce successful experience from previous Joint Program in San Marcos Region. The program intents to: improve livelihoods, health and resilience of poor peasant families with productions of subsistence and Infra subsistence in rural poor areas of Comitancillo, San Miguel Ixtahuacán, Concepción Tutuapa, Sipacapa y Tejutla of San Marcos, Guatemala. The program will also strength capacities of civil society, local and central government with presence in the area to enhance the preparation and implementation of Municipal Development Plan and promote participation on Development Council System as a way to reach investment on the region.
