policy-marker.narrative: Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention on Biological Diversity
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention to Combat Desertification
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Adaptation
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Mitigation
Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn and Child Health (RMNCH)

description.narrative: Implementation during 2020 was conditioned by COVID-19 pandemic, the joint program was able to take measures to continue the implementation in a COVID-19 context, such as changes in operations to face the country lock down, design and implementation of a COVID-19 response plan. The program's operations changed regarding training sessions, groups were divided in groups of 10, gel alcohol and face masks were provided and physical distance between participants was assured; information about COVID-19 prevention was introduced to support the containment of the pandemic; a response plan was designed and implemented to support the most vulnerable families to go through the lock downs and the economic consequences of the pandemic. Municipalities: Municipal governments increased their capacity to plan and promote territorial development processes, introducing watershed management approaches, risk management and promoting gender equality and women empowerment, the municipal offices strengthened were: DMM, UMGAR, OMC, OFM, DMP, UMAIP, OMJNA, OMAS. 5 municipal strategies to strengthen public services were updated, approved, and implemented, including a Covid-19 prevention plan. To achieve this, the Municipal Office of Public Services (OMSP), the office for Water and Sanitation (OMAS), OMESS and OMDEL were strengthened. Democratic governance was supported through the communitarian development councils COMUDE's permanent commissions that were strengthened through capacity building to enhance more interaction with the population to reach more participatory and inclusive solutions to citizen demands. Ministry of Health - MSPAS The Comprehensive Center for Maternal and Child Care (CAIMI) of Tejutla was supported with equipment and supplies for water quality monitoring, anthropometric equipment, laboratory supplies and equipment,, ultrasound and electrocardiograph. Implementation of the Telemedicine Network was developed through the Comprehensive Center for Maternal and Child Care (CAIMI) of Tejutla and the Permanent Care Centers (CAP) of Comitancillo and Concepción Tutuapa. Training was provided for health personnel in the five Municipal Health Districts (DMS) for the prevention of COVID-19. Technical support was provided to update the Municipal Health Plan (PMS). The planning processes between DMS and the municipalities was supported through training and capacity building for the Municipal Development Councils (COMUDE), the Municipal Food and Nutrition Security Commissions (COMUSAN), the Municipal Water and Sanitation Offices (OMAS), the Municipal Directorate for Women (DMM). Ministry of Agriculture - MAGA Ministry of Agriculture received support to train and strengthen local extension services to implement the Family Agriculture Program – PAFFEC. MAGA scaled up the multipurpose rainwater harvesting model, which has been implemented within San Marcos, other departments by several organizations, and families with remittances with technical assistance from MAGA. With the Joint Program support the Ministry of Agriculture in San Marcos was able to support food systems and food security by: Provision of seeds to families for family gardens; Build and improve productive infrastructure; Implement seedling nurseries; Support the implementation of short circuits of commercialization of the School Feeding Program - PAE Networks; Prepare a protocol for COVID-19 prevention in community markets. Planning Secretariat - SEGEPLAN The Joint Program supported SEGEPLAN to develop guides and tools to provide technical assistance in planning to public institutions, local governments, and the System of Development Councils at the departmental, municipal and community levels. Secretariat for disaster risk reduction - SECONRED The support provided by the Joint Program allowed SECONRED to improve its instruments and strengthen the mechanisms to guarantee the coordination with the public and private institutions for disaster risk management in San Marcos. Food Security Food insecurity and its consequences is a huge problem in Guatemala, which has increased in 2020 as a consequence of COVID-19 pandemic. Even so, the joint program managed to ensure that 60% of the low-income and subsistence families that participate in the program (1,750) reduced their food insecurity (moderate and severe), which is twice the planned final goal (30%). As well, the program increased the availability and diversity of food with a diet diversity index (DDI) of (9.01) in 2020 compared to DDI (6.96) in 2015. 52 community promoters (29women / 23men) have joined the National Rural Extension System (SNER)exceeding the goal of 45. Safe, Healthy, and Productive Family Habitat 454 families living in conditions of very high and high vulnerability to natural disasters received training to manage the risks present in their family habitat (home + environment), achieving a dignified, healthy, safe, sustainable, and resilient environment to face extreme events.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

sida:strategy.sida:title: Guatemala 2016-2020
sida:strategy.sida:titleSV: Guatemala 2016-2020

title.narrative: UNDP - Ixil Rural Development Joint Program

description.narrative: Omprogrammerade medel för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 Insatsen ”Gemensamma programmet för landsbygdsutveckling i Ixil” har utvecklats under ramverket för den i övergångsrättvisa förekommande principen om icke-upprepning (aldrig mer-principen) såsom ett svar på en begäran från offren under den interna väpnade konflikten i Guatemala om att adressera möjligheten till ekonomiska och andra utvecklingsmöjligheter på lokal nivå och som ett komplement till "Program till stöd för övergångsrättvisa i Guatemala PAJUST", vilket stöds och har stötts av Sverige under flera år. Programmet är ett integrerat landsbygdsutvecklingsprogram som har som mål att öka återhämtningsmöjligheterna för de familjer som föll offer för den interna väpnade konflikten i Santa María Nebaj, Cotzal och Chajul, som samtliga tillhör regionen Quiché i Guatemala genom en helhetssyn på landsbygdsutveckling vilken även omfattar ett hållbart brukande och förvaltning av naturresurser. Helhetssynen omfattar att arbeta med familjer som driver småbruk för det egna uppehället, för att förbättra familjernas hälsa, näringsintag, boende och närområde, förvaltning och hantering av utveckling ifråga om resurser och naturresurser samt kunskaper i företagande. Programmet kombinerar sagda teman med att arbeta med lokala och centrala myndigheter verksamma i Ixil för att utveckla och förbättra kunskaperna inom staten för att uppnå ett inkluderande och fredligt styre utifrån ett rättighets- och återhämtningsperspektiv.

Reprogrammed funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 The program Ixil Rural Development Joint Program has been designed under the framework of non-repetition measures of Transitional Justice, as a response to armed conflict victims request to access to economic and local development opportunities and as a complement to PAJUST- Transitional Justice Program sponsored by Embassy of Sweden in Guatemala. The program is an integral rural development program that aims to increase resilience of families victims of armed conflict in Santa María Nebaj, Cotzal and Chajul, department of Quiché,Guatemala, through a holistic rural development approach and natural resources sustainable management. The holistic approach includes working with families with agricultural productions subsistence and infra subsistence to improve their health, nutrition, habitat, development management, natural resources governance and their entrepreneurship capabilities. As well as, working with local government and central government institutions delegated in the Ixil region to develop capacities to reach inclusive and pacific governance with a rights approach and a culture of resilience.

Rural Development Joint Program Ixil implements rural development actions in Ixil Area also with Swedish funding. Outcome 1:Families victims of internal armed conflict in subsistence and infra-subsistence conditions and community organizations with increased capacities to improve their habitat, knowledge, renewable natural resource management, health and entrepreneurial skills.Outcome 2:Local governments and sectorial institutions of Ixil region with increased capacities to achieve peaceful and inclusive governance with human rights and resilience approach.

tag.narrative: 1.5 - By 2030, build the resilience of the poor and those in vulnerable situations and reduce their exposure and vulnerability to climate-related extreme events and other economic, social and environmental shocks and disasters.

1.5 - Till 2030 bygga upp motståndskraften hos de fattiga och människor i utsatta situationer och minska deras utsatthet och sårbarhet för extrema klimatrelaterade händelser och andra ekonomiska, sociala och miljömässiga chocker och katastrofer.
13.1 - Strengthen resilience and adaptive capacity to climate-related hazards and natural disasters in all countries.
13.1 - Stärka motståndskraften mot och förmågan till anpassning till klimatrelaterade faror och naturkatastrofer i alla länder.

2.4 - By 2030, ensure sustainable food production systems and implement resilient agricultural practices that increase productivity and production, that help maintain ecosystems, that strengthen capacity for adaptation to climate change, extreme weather, drought, flooding and other disasters and that progressively improve land and soil quality.

2.4 - Senast 2030 uppnå hållbara system för livsmedelsproduktion samt införa motståndskraftiga jordbruksmetoder som ökar produktiviteten och produktionen, som bidrar till att upprätthålla ekosystemen, som stärker förmågan till anpassning till klimatförändringar, extrema väderförhållanden, torka, översvämning och andra katastrofer och som successivt förbättrar mark- och jordkvaliteten.
3.1 - By 2030, reduce the global maternal mortality ratio to less than 70 per 100,000 live births.
3.1 - Till 2030 minska mödradödligheten i världen till mindre än 70 dödsfall per 100 000 förlossningar med levande barn.
5.5 - Ensure women’s full and effective participation and equal opportunities for leadership at all levels of decision-making in political, economic and public life.
5.5 - Tillförsäkra kvinnor fullt och faktiskt deltagande och lika möjligheter till ledarskap på alla beslutsnivåer i det politiska, ekonomiska och offentliga livet.

5.6 - Ensure universal access to sexual and reproductive health and reproductive rights as agreed in accordance with the Programme of Action of the International Conference on Population and Development and the Beijing Platform for Action and the outcome documents of their review conferences.

5.6 - Säkerställa allmän tillgång till sexuell och reproduktiv hälsa och reproduktiva rättigheter i enlighet med överenskommelserna i handlingsprogrammet från den internationella konferensen om befolkning och utveckling, Pekingplattformen samt slutdokumenten från respektive översynskonferenser.
6.6 - By 2020, protect and restore water-related ecosystems, including mountains, forests, wetlands, rivers, aquifers and lakes.
6.6 - Senast 2020 skydda och återställa de vattenrelaterade ekosystemen, däribland berg, skogar, våtmarker, floder, akviferer och sjöar.
6.b - Stödja och stärka lokalsamhällenas deltagande i arbetet med att förbättra vatten- och sanitetshanteringen.
6.b - Support and strengthen the participation of local communities in improving water and sanitation management.

description.narrative: The Joint Program`s 2020 implementation was marked by the COVID-19 pandemic that considerably affected the conditions of families and communities in the Ixil region since March 2020 and the tropical storms ETA and IOTA in November 2020. The Ixil Joint Program contributed to strengthen capacities of sectorial institutions and local governments (duty bearers), to facilitate the territorialization of public policies related to rural development and public investment to meet citizens demands. The Program successfully managed to link sectoral institutions to municipal work through the transfer of knowledge, support the design of function manuals and regulations, increased citizen participation, support strategic and operational planning, support to ensure access to public information. 2020 was the last year of implementation of the Ixil JP, the objectives of the program have been achieved such as a reduction in maternal death, families have reduced vulnerabilities in health determinants, increased access and use of health services, women in positions of decision-making in civil society organizations, women with expanded economic opportunities by establishing agricultural and non-agricultural enterprises, bringing institutions and public investment closer to the territory, and generating an improvement in the quality of life of families. Some of the achievements are: i) Increased municipal income to Q9.0 M (2020) compared to Q2.5 M (2015) ii) Increased financial resources assigned by Development Council System - SISCODE to municipalities in 2020 (Q23.5M) in comparison to 2015 (Q7.0M); and, iii) two municipalities (Nebaj and Cotzal) improved their municipal management, going from a low category in 2013 to a medium category in 2018, due to their improvements in democratic governance, citizen participation, access to public information and administrative management indicators. The program has also contributed to the empowerment of more than 3,000 families (rights holders) through the knowledge transfer and the implementation of good practices in health and hygiene, food production, water and sanitation, family habitat, productive enterprises, improving the maternal and child health, food and nutrition security, habitability and income.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

title.narrative: Amendment of agreement between Sida and World Bank Rapid Social Response 2020
Beslut om ändring av avtal mellan Sida och World Bank Rapid Social Response 2020

description.narrative: The Rapid Social Response Multi-donor Trust Fund was designed as a response to meet the effects of the financial crises in 2008-2009. Overall it has had extensive effects for promoting expansion of social protection as a tool to reduce poverty. In 2020 a quick response was made to enable support to develop system for social protection to meet the economic effects of the pandemic COVID-19. Since its inception the RSR has approved 291 activities in 100 countries with support amounting to 131 million USD, including the latest call for proposals undertaken in late 2020. It is estimated that the RSR through strategic interventions has contributed to leverage 10,8 billion USD in financing from the International Devleopment Association (IDA). The systems reviews, studies and development of capacity and technical know-how has formed the basis for designing and implementing large-scale social protection programmes that reaches an estimated 176 million people. A specific component of the RSR is targeted to knowledge generation with policy and methods development which is essential for expansion of the right to social protection. The RSR has gathered practioners in partner countries for knowledge exhange and dialogue in South-South learning forums that has gathered over 1600 participants from 100 countries and also has a "community of practice" for countinous exchange with over 570 participants. During the last two years physical conferences have not been possible, instead a digital conference was organized in May 2021; "Social Protection and Jobs Core Knowledge Exchange" with a large number of participants attending presentations and engaging in discussions. RSR reports on results bi-annually with a delay in reports which means the latest report covering 2017 to December 2018 was received in November 2019. The report was discussed at a donor meeting in Ankara in November 2019, with Sida participating on-line. In the latest reported period 2017-2018 there is a decline in approved applications during 2018 which also reflects the decline in the available budget for the RSR MDTF. In December 2018, 5,3 MUSD remained of the total budget of 112MUSD. An updated budget overview in November 2019 showed that 3,8MUSD remained of the total budget of the RSR Classic. The main donors that have contributed to the RSR are; Russia, United Kingdom (DFID), Norway, Sweden, Australia and Denmark, Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation, and GFDRR (Global Facility for Disaster Risk Reduction). During the implementation period, the original RSR MDTF has been complemented with specific "windows" with ear-marked thematic support. Russia has supported a window on nutrition-sensitive social protection, while Denmark has support a window focused on youth. In late 2018 the RSR MDTF was complemented with a gender window focused on gender-integration in social protection schemes, which was supported by DFID and Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation with in total 12,2 MUSD. In March 2020, Australia agreed to provide additional funds to the original trust fund "RSR Classic" to support governments to rapidly develop strategies to meet the challenge of increased poverty during the Covid-19 pandemic. Sida also agreed to contribution additional funding of 20 MSEK in mid-2020 to "RSR Classic" with the same purpose. Additional funding in 2021 enabled Round 19 of calls for proposals to "RSR Classic" and "RSR Gender-Smart". The focus of this round was to develop Social Protection and Jobs policies to help clients develop green, resilient, and inclusive social protection programs and systems that help individuals and families, especially the poor and vulnerable, cope with crises and shocks, build resilience, find jobs, improve productivity and productive inclusion, invest in health and education, and protect the population in time of crisis. A total of 51 proposals were submitted by the deadline July 30, 2021, amounting to USD 11.7 million. A rapid selection process will be undertaken to allocate the USD 3.2 million available for the call. All activities under RSR Classic need to be completed by mid-2022 and in RSR Gender Smart by mid-2023. The wide scope of the RSR has made aggregation of results challenging, while results are clear in the large number of satisfactory interventions that have been financed which has resulted in development of key aspects of social protection systems in 100 countries. The targeted windows have provided a clearer overview of results and has also enabled focus on strategic aspects. The gender-window supported by DFID was a result of low priority of gender integration in the initiatives that applied for support from the RSR. A few highlights can be mentioned to provide examples of results achieved from the 300 initiatives that were supported during 2017-2018 to improve social protection and labour systems components and architecture to which over 22 MUSD were allocated. In Botswana the RSR grant contributed to the preparation of a comprehensive National Social Protection Framework which provides a road-map for a coordinated nutrition-sensitive and schock-responsive social protection system. A division of labour and respsonsibility for different stakeholders was developed as well as a proposal of how to integrate nutrition into social protection programming. The RSR financed acitivites also contributed to development of a single registry of beneficiaires to improve the efficiency of social protection. In addition, a social intermediation strategy was developed with a focus on supporting beneficiaries to "graduate" from social assistance to labour market programs. In Sierra Leone the RSR financed activities that increased the effectiveness of the social protection program. Technical assistance during the Ebola recovery period and during floods and landslide emergencies supported development of the social safety net system and expansion of standardised cash transfers in the country. The grant also facilitated national dialogue about social protection issues for the revision of the social protection policy. The revised social protection poliy was later approved by the Cabinet. The RSR also supports policy development, for example in 2019 publishing the book "Exploring Universal Basic Income - A Guide to Navigating Concepts, Evidence and Practices". The book has supported learning and discussion on key issues in social protection relating to targeting or universal approaches and on how the term "universal" can be interpreted.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

strategy.title: Swedish Strategy for global development cooperation on sustainable economic development 2018 – 2022
strategy.titleSV: Sveriges globala utvecklingssamarbete inom hållbar ekonomisk utveckling 2018-2022

description.narrative:
Omprogrammerade medel för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 Stockholm Resilience Centre (SRC) har ansökt hos Sida om ett stöd på 141,2 miljoner kr för att genomföra det globala programmet ”SwedBio – a knowledge interface on resilience and development at Stockholm Resilience Centre” under fyra år 2016-2019.
Programmet har som mål att bidra till utvecklingen av resilienta ekosystem och samhällen med minskad fattigdom och respekterade mänskliga rättigheter. Detta vill man bidra till att uppnå genom utveckling av politik, policyer och metoder på internationell, nationell och i viss mån, lokal nivå. Verksamheten har en särskild styrka i SwedBios långsiktiga samarbete med 10-12 frivilligorganisationer som i huvudsak har sin bas i utvecklingsländer. Ett särdrag hos SwedBio är deras arbete med att fungera som ett ”gränssnitt för kunskap” (knowledge interface) och förbättra dialogen mellan olika aktörer, från ursprungsfolk och folkrörelser till det internationella forskarsamfundet och FN-förhandlare. De skräddarsydda dialogseminarier som SwedBio arrangerat i Ekvador, Panama och Colombia sedan 2012 i syfte att bl a underlätta förhandlingar inom konventionen för biologisk mångfald är några exempel på hur man arbetar.
SwedBio startades på initiativ från Sida år 2002 och inhystes fram till 2011 på Centrum för Biologisk mångfald på Sveriges Lantbruksuniversitet. 2011 bytte programmet värd till Stockholm Resilience Centre (SRC) och är numera en integrerad del av SRC.
Parallellt med detta beslut fattar Sida beslut om stöd till SRC för att genomföra programmet "Guidance for Resilience in the Anthropocene: Investments for Development 2015-2019" (GRAID), insatsnr 61050180.
Ansvarsfördelningen är följande: Stockholms universitet är avtalspart eftersom Stockholm Resilience Centre inte är en egen organisation utan ligger under fakulteten för naturvetenskap på Stockholms universitet. Stockholm Resilience Centre och dess styrelse har dock ansvar för att programmet genomförs enligt överenskommelse. SwedBio-programmets enhetschef har viss delegerad beslutskapacitet och ansvarar för den dagliga verksamheten. SwedBios personal inklusive enhetschef finansieras av SwedBios programbudget.

Reprogrammed funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 A knowledge-interface programme initiated by Sida in 2002 to strengthen resilience & sustainable development as a tool for poverty reduction. SwedBio is now a programme under the Stockholm Resisilience Centre, Stockholm University. During recent years SwedBio has been developing towards a more detached, international think-tank with a reduced dependency of Sida.

strategy.title: Sustainable environment, climate, oceans and use of natural resources 2018-2022
strategy.titleSV: Hållbar miljö, hållbart klimat och hav samt hållbart nyttj. av naturresurser 2018-2022

description.narrative:
Omprogrammerade medel för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 En långsiktigt hållbar utveckling och varaktig fattigdomsbekämpning förutsätter att alla tre nödvändiga pelare för en hållbar utveckling, d.v.s ekonomiska, sociala och miljömässiga aspekter, aktivt integreras i samhällsutvecklingen. Miljöekonomisk forskning, metodutveckling och kapacitetsbyggande är viktiga delar i detta arbete, vilka kan bidra väsentligt till framtagande av planer, policies och lagstiftning - lokalt, nationellt, regionalt och globalt.
Sida har sedan början av 1990-talet stött miljöekonomisk kapacitetsuppbyggnad vid Enheten för miljöekonomi, EME, vid Göteborgs universitet genom ett doktorandprogram i miljöekonomi för studenter från syd. Genom åren har ett betydande antal disputerade doktorander lämnat Göteborg för att fortsätta sina akademiska karriärer i sina repektive hemländer.
Efterhand som dessa började återvända till sina hemländer blev det uppenbart att det i de flesta länder i syd saknas kapacitet på miljöekonomiområdet, liksom institutionella förutsättningar att arbeta med dessa frågor. Som incitament för att kunna fortsätta att arbeta med tillämpad miljöekonomisk forskning och metodutveckling, samt använda denna för att förstärka nationella beslutsprocesser och policies, krävdes tillgång till resurser, akademisk infrastruktur och konkreta möjligheter för forskarna att arbeta inom sitt expertområde. Som ett svar på dessa behov startade under 2006, på initiativ av EME och några av de forskare som lämnat Göteborg för sina hemländer, programmet "The Environment for Development Initiative", EfD.
Programmet, som är uppbyggt som ett nätverk av nationella miljöekonomiska center, arbetar med miljöekonomisk kapacitetsuppbyggnad, tillämpad miljöekonomisk forskning, samt aktivt policy och kommunikationsarbete för att föra ut resultat och påverka policies och beslutsfattare. Nätverket består för närvarande av sex nationella miljöekonomiska center i Kenya, Tanzania, Etiopien, Sydafrika, Costa Rica och Kina och programmet koordineras och stöds av ett sekretariat vid Göteborgs universitet. Att just dessa länder ingår beror på att det här vid starten fanns intresserade forskare med svensk utbildning samt relevanta akademiska institutioner att etablera centren vid.
EfD-programmet är ett av Sidas få stöd till global tillämpad miljöekonomisk forskning, kapacitetsutveckling och policypåverkan, och det enda som fokuserar helt på detta. Sidas engagemang har varit långsiktigt och programmet har över åren byggt upp en förhållandevis stark kapacitet och resursbas med stark förankring i de länder centren är stationerade. Resultaten har över lag varit goda, både enligt Sidas erfarenheter och enligt gjorda utvärderingar, och det är Sidas bedömning att ett fortsatt och utökat stöd kan bygga vidare på redan uppnådda resultat.
Göteborgs universitet föreslår i den nu liggande ansökan en kraftig ökning av programmets budget från 14-18 MSEK/år under nuvarande avtal till 25-28 MSEK/år för perioden 2016 - 2020. Huvuddelen av budgetökningen motiveras av en utökning av den tillämpade forskningen vid de enskilda centren, utökat forskningssamarbete centren emellan, samt etablering, och inkludering i nätverket, av tre till fem nya center.
Det är Sidas bedömning att en ökning av Sidas nuvarande stöd enligt ansökan under den kommande femårsperioden kan motiveras från ett relevans-, kapacitets- och resultatperspektiv. Sida har goda erfarenheter av verksamheten och dess resultat från tidigare samarbete. Det är även Sidas bedömning att EfD-programmet i sin helhet, liksom de enskilda centren, har akademisk och administrativ kapacitet att hantera en väsentlig utökning av verksamhetens budget och arbetsvolym, både vad gäller omfattningen på forskningsverksamheten och policy- och kommunikationsarbetet. Sida bedömer även att det är rimligt att, under den kommande programperioden, inkludera tre nya center med relativt god kapacitet för att snabbt kunna etablera verksamheten, bidra till programmets gemensamma arbete och skapa goda resultat i form av forskning och policypåverkan. Det är även Sidas bedömning att programmet har kapacitet att inkludera ytterligare ett eller två center vid lämpliga institutioner i låginkomstländer. Eftersom förutsättningarna för att etablera sådana center i miljöer med mycket låg kapacitet är svaga kräver detta längre förberedelsetid och mer arbete än att inkludera center med bättre förutsättningar.
EfDs arbete är även mycket relevant i förhållande till gällande strategier för utvecklingssamarbetet, fattigdomsfrågor och, inte minst, det akuta globala, nationella och lokala behovet av att sträva mot en miljömässigt hållbar utveckling. Många av de frågor EfD arbetar med har även stark relevans för de nyligen antagna SDG-målen (Sustainable Development Goals) som tex klimat, energi, biodiversitet, hållbar produktion och konsumtion och ekonomisk tillväxt.

Reprogrammed funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 Support to environmental economics reserach, capacity building and policy development. Cooperation between Gothenburg University and a number of policy centers mainly in Africa.

description.narrative: EfD’s huvudsakliga syfte är att bidra till effektiv naturresursförvaltning i Globala syd genom ökad användning av evidensbaserad miljöekonomi i policyarbete. Insatsen ska bidra till i huvudsak till 3 mål i Strategin för Sveriges globala utvecklingssamarbete inom hållbar miljö, hållbart klimat och hav, samt hållbart nyttjande av naturresurser 2018–2022. - Minskad sårbarhet hos människor som lever i fattigdom, och ökad motståndskraft att hantera klimatförändringar och naturkatastrofer. 50% - Stärkt skydd och återställande, samt hållbar förvaltning och hållbart nyttjande av landbaserade ekosystem, biologisk mångfald och arter, naturresurser, inklusive jord- och skogsbruk, samt ekosystemtjänster. 35% - Stärkt skydd och återställande, samt hållbar förvaltning och hållbart nyttjande av marina, kustnära och sötvatten-ekosystem, biologisk mångfald, naturresurser, samt ekosystemtjänster. 15%. EfD-programmet har dock en mycket bred ansats och levererar till betydligt fler av målen i aktuellt strategi. Nästa fas av insaten har taggats med fler mål i Plan-it. Nedan exempel på resultat från narrativ årsrapport 2019. EfD program developments 1a januari 2019 blev EfDs globala hub en egen enhet vid Göteborgs Universitet och inkluderar både administration, ledning och forskare. EfD-nätverket har vuxit kraftigt de senaste åren (tre nya center öppnades 2016) och 2019 expanderade nätverket till att inkludera ytterligare tre nya center: Nigeria: The Resource and Environmental Policy Research Centre (REPRC) vid University of Nsukka. Uganda: EfD-Mak tillsammans med the School of Economics och Department of Agribusiness and Natural Resource Economics vid Makerere University och Ghana: The Environment and Natural Resource Research Unit (ENRRU) vid the Department of Economics vid University of Ghana. Under 2019 publicerade EfDs forskare 158 research outputs vilket inkluderar peer-reviewed artiklar, discussion papers, policy briefs, research briefs och bok kapitel. En extern utvärdering utfördes av EfD-programmet EnvEcon vilken konfirmerade EfD-nätverkets relevans och tyngd inom miljöekonomi och utveckling. Från utvärderingen: "Our engagement with the EfD Initiative and, in particular, with external stakeholders as part of this and theprior evaluation, offers sustained evidence that the approach and contribution of the EfD Initiative is substantive, appropriate and impactful. Evidence shows that the Intervention Logic is sustained in terms ofthe stated aim of contributing to poverty alleviation and the effective management of the environment in the Global South through applied research, institutional development and policy interaction. We find the performance levels are at a point appropriate to this stage of the Network’s evolution and development. There is clear evidence, and external recognition, of the alignment of the EfD Centres to local priorities and needs; the importance of the development and availability of local trusted expertise; and the impact – both direct and indirect – that EfD research and EfD individuals, deliver in terms of tangible progress on the EfD Initiative vision. The reputation of the Network has grown substantially since the last evaluation based on considerable work from EfD Secretariat, the Centres and the commitment of many individuals involved in the Network." EfDs årsmöte hölls i Bogota i nov 2019 och är nu en världsledande konferens inom miljöekonomi och utveckling. Detta år fokuserades på genderfrågor. EfD har som ansats att aktivt bidra till den normativa dialogen vid globala policyrelaterade möten och under 2020 bjöds t ex EfD´s Director till the High Level Political Forum on Sustainable Development i New York. EfD har procuderat ett antal impact stories med koppling till viktiga miljöproblem. Ett viktigt resultat är att arbetet med värdering av ekosystemtjänster har visats i en video produced av BBC och delats av the International Association of Universities. Impact stories: Resultatområde: Minskad sårbarhet hos människor som lever i fattigdom, och ökad motståndskraft att hantera klimatförändringar och naturkatastrofer. EfD South Africa: Saving Water at Cape Town Schools by using Smart Metering & Behavioural ChangeDuring the Cape Town water crisis in 2018, The Environmental-Economics Policy Research Unit EPRU and BridgIoT, an internet of things (IoT) systems integrator and solutions developer based at Stellenbosch University, combined smart water meters, basic infrastructure upgrades and behavioural interventions to reduce water usage at schools in the Western Cape, South Africa. The project was sponsored by Shoprite Holdings, Shoprite suppliers, the Western Cape Department of Education, the Department of the Premier and EfD. In the first part of the project, a total of 345 schools received smart water meters and maintenance upgrades. In the second part, two behaviour interventions were tested on a subset of 120 schools: (1) a weekly feedback report with graphical representations of a school’s water usage and (2) a combination of the feedback report and an inter school competition. The maintenance campaign reduced a school’s water leaks by 28% within five days. The behavioural interventions led to water usage reductions of between 15 and 26%. The collaborative project achieved significant cost savings at schools. For example one of the winning water-saving schools, Cravenby Secondary school, a 400KL reduction was recorded which was valued at R38 915. Based on these results, a detailed cost-benefit analysis and report was prepared to motivate for the smart water meters to be rolled out to additional schools around the province, which was presented to the Western Cape Government. Resultat: Stärkt skydd och återställande, samt hållbar förvaltning och hållbart nyttjande av landbaserade ekosystem, biologisk mångfald och arter, naturresurser, inklusive jord- och skogsbruk, samt ekosystemtjänster. 35% EfD-Vietnam Contribute to the Integration of Economic Policy Instruments in Environmental LawDuring last decade, EfD-Vietnam researchers have explored and conducted various studies related to the environmental management in this country, from the biofuel consumption,mangrove forest devolution, urban waste management, fresh water usage and energy savings to the stakeholder’s preferences and the cooperation in the society, etc. These certified outcomes on good international peer-reviewed journals have accumulatively created opportunities to transfer the message on environmental management to policymakers. On 10 November 2019, by the request of the Minister, EfD-Vietnam together with the Ministry of Natural Resources and Environment Institute of Strategy and Policy discussed the draft of the law and focused mainly on the new chapter. In addition to the basic principles of environmental policy adopted in the Environmental Laws from developed and developing countries, various types of environmental management tools are discussed in detail, including: (i) Regulatory tools (Technology standards and performance standards); (ii) Market-based instruments (Taxes, fees, charges, subsidy, deposit & refund, tradable permits); (iii) Information-based tools (Voluntary agreements, information provision, education); and (iv) Other tools (such as Research & Development, behavioral nudges, and legal responsibility). In which, the content of tools based on Market-Based Approaches was discussed in depth and thoroughly including tax, non-tax and ownership for the tradeable emission permits market and the emissions reducing credits. Resultatområde: Stärkt skydd och återställande, samt hållbar förvaltning och hållbart nyttjande av marina, kustnära och sötvatten-ekosystem, biologisk mångfald, naturresurser, samt ekosystemtjänster. EfD Nigeria: REPRC-EfD Research Leads to a Recommendation to Review Nigeria’s Fishery ActFollowing the data collection process for the Fishery Performance Indicators, researchers at The Resource and Environmental Policy Research Centre, Environment for Development (REPRC-EfD) Nigeria interacted with various policy makers and organized a Policy outreach in Abuja, October 2019.Presenting findings of the EfD funded research, Dr Ebele Amaechina said that Nigerian marine artisanal fishery performed below and worse than the average of all African fisheries and therefore required urgent intervention. She recommended an immediate stop to artisanal open access fishery in Nigeria by defining who is entitled to fish or not at each point in time. The study also recommended the involvement of fishermen in regulating access and use of unwanted gears. This could be achieved by creating a beach management unit in every landing site. Dr Nnaemeka Chukwuone noted a shortfall in Nigeria’s Fisheries Act of 1992, which he said contained regulations only for industrial fishermen who fish above five nautical miles but contained virtually no regulation for artisanal fishing in the lower shelf. He proposed a review of Nigeria’s Fishery Act of 1992 to accommodate regulatory measures that will curtail the depletion of fish and other aquatic creatures in Nigeria’s shelf. EfD Central America: Circular Economy - Maximizing the Reuse of ResourcesThe Circular Economy generates 1.1 % of GDP worldwide, and it is an alternative system for Costa Rica, where the reuse of materials can allow the generation of business and economic opportunities, and at the same time, provides societal and environmental benefits. In Costa Rica, this circular economy approach will facilitate the implementation of the 2018 – 2050 National Decarbonization Plan, announced by the Costa Rican government at the beginning of 2019.The EfD Center in Central America, through applied research and continued policy interaction with decision makers at the national and local level, paved the way for the country to start working under a circular economy approach. This as a first tangible result of a new research area of research and policy interaction for EfD Central America.During the Policy Day held on December 2019, the Municipality of Turrialba and the Ministry of Environment and Energy (MINAE), signed a letter of understanding that aims to generate a case study at the municipal level for the implementation of the project entitled “Towards a circular economy of local government in Costa Rica”.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

description.narrative:
Omprogrammerade medel för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 UN-Water (UNW) är en organisation för samordning och informationsutbyte mellan 31 olika FN-organ, organisationer och program som arbetar med vattenresurser, dricksvatten och sanitet. Genom att stödja gemensamma insatser och skapa synergieffekter mellan ytterligare 36 icke-FN-organisationer skapas ett mervärde för genomförande av pågående och planerade FN-program och projekt. Denna beredning avser ett stöd till UN Water 2015-2020. Totalt avtalsbelopp med Sida för perioden är 36 mn skr och hela strategin är på ca 28 mn USD (200 mn skr) inklusive andra givares främst Schweiz, men också FN organisationernas medfinansiering .
Avsteg från Sidas insatsregel har noterats vad gäller paragraf 2.8.11. Krav på revision och revisionsstandrard: Sverige har som medlem i FN deltagit i beslut om att acceptera externa och interna revisionsprocesser utifrån gjord riskanalys, SingleAudit principle samt § 2.8.7 Korruption om att Avtalet ska ange att samarbetsparten omedelbart ska informera Sida vid misstankar om eller förekomst av korruption.
Schweiz (SDC) har för avsikt att fortsätta sitt stöd gör en beredning senare i år och Sida har en regelbunden diskussion med dom, om framtida stöd och delar dokument. Detta är anledningen till att Sidas bedömning skrivs på engelska.

Reprogrammed funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 UN-Water(UNW) is an inter-agency mechanism. UNW functions as a body for coordinating and information sharing among 28 different UN agencies, organisations and programmes working with issues related to water resources, drinking water & sanit. By supporting joint efforts and synergies between an additional 24 non-UN partners, added value is made to implem. of ongoing and/or planned UN programs/projects.

participating-org.narrative: UNOPS/United Nations Office for Project Services
United Nations Office for Project Services

sector.narrative: Water sector policy and administrative management

tag.narrative: 6.1 - By 2030, achieve universal and equitable access to safe and affordable drinking water for all.
6.1 - Senast 2030 uppnå allmän och rättvis tillgång till säkert och ekonomiskt överkomligt dricksvatten för alla.

6.2 - By 2030, achieve access to adequate and equitable sanitation and hygiene for all and end open defecation, paying special attention to the needs of women and girls and those in vulnerable situations.

6.2 - Senast 2030 säkerställa att alla har tillgång till fullgod och rättvis sanitet och hygien och att ingen behöver uträtta sina behov utomhus. Särskild uppmärksamhet bör ägnas åt behoven hos kvinnor och flickor samt människor i utsatta situationer.

6.3 - By 2030, improve water quality by reducing pollution, eliminating dumping and minimizing release of hazardous chemicals and materials, halving the proportion of untreated wastewater and substantially increasing recycling and safe reuse globally.

6.3 - Till 2030 förbättra vattenkvaliteten genom att minska föroreningar, stoppa dumpning och minimera utsläpp av farliga kemikalier och material, halvera andelen obehandlat avloppsvatten och väsentligt öka återvinningen och en säker återanvändning globalt.

6.4 - By 2030, substantially increase water-use efficiency across all sectors and ensure sustainable withdrawals and supply of freshwater to address water scarcity and substantially reduce the number of people suffering from water scarcity.

6.4 - Till 2030 väsentligt effektivisera vattenanvändningen inom alla sektorer samt säkerställa hållbara uttag och en hållbar försörjning med sötvatten för att angripa vattenbristen och väsentligt minska det antal människor som lider av vattenbrist.
6.5 - By 2030, implement integrated water resources management at all levels, including through transboundary cooperation as appropriate.
6.5 - Senast 2030 genomföra en integrerad förvaltning av vattenresurser på alla nivåer, när så är lämpligt genom gränsöverskridande samarbete.
6.6 - By 2020, protect and restore water-related ecosystems, including mountains, forests, wetlands, rivers, aquifers and lakes.
6.6 - Senast 2020 skydda och återställa de vattenrelaterade ekosystemen, däribland berg, skogar, våtmarker, floder, akviferer och sjöar.

6.a - By 2030, expand international cooperation and capacity-building support to developing countries in water- and sanitation-related activities and programmes, including water harvesting, desalination, water efficiency, wastewater treatment, recycling and reuse technologies.

6.a - Till 2030 utöka det internationella samarbetet och stödet för kapacitetsuppbyggnad till utvecklingsländerna inom vatten- och sanitetsrelaterade verksamheter och program, inklusive genom tekniker för vatteninsamling, avsaltning, vatteneffektivitet, rening av avloppsvatten, återvinning och återanvändning.
6.b - Stödja och stärka lokalsamhällenas deltagande i arbetet med att förbättra vatten- och sanitetshanteringen.
6.b - Support and strengthen the participation of local communities in improving water and sanitation management.

description.narrative:
New/additional funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 Education is a human right and necessary to be able to exercise the other human rights. Education promotes freedom and autonomy and contributes to development. Despite this, millions of children, young people and adults lack access to educational opportunities. And for many, poverty is the underlying cause. Education in poor countries is severely underfunded. UNESCO estimates that $ 39 billion a year is needed, in addition to countries' domestic resources, to guarantee all children a full education, from preschool to high school.
GPE's overall goals are improved educational outcomes for all - girls and boys, young women and young men - through equal and equal access to good quality education. Special focus is placed on the poorest and those who are most marginalized as a result of gender, disability, ethnicity, conflict or other vulnerability. GPE also draws attention to the importance of teachers having the capacity and knowledge to teach in an adequate manner and that the education systems, including the education plans, are designed to effectively convey adequate and relevant education.
Countries eligible for GPE grants may receive support to either develop training plans or to implement already approved plans. Since its inception in 2002, GPE has allocated a total of $ 4.4 billion to education in the world's poorest countries.
GPE is governed by a board consisting of 19 members who represent the partnership's various actors. The Board consists of six donor constituencies, six constituencies representing the partner countries, three multilateral bodies (UNICEF, UNESCO and the World Bank), three representatives of civil society organizations and one for the private sector and foundations. Sweden and Denmark constitute a constituency.
Sida estimates that GPE has developed a lot during its 14 years of operation. GPE differs from other global initiatives in that the working model is based on clear national ownership and equal partnerships between donors and partner countries. GPE has the role both as a contributor, coordinator and as an influencer to increase the understanding of the importance of education for sustainable development.
Sweden has supported GPE since its inception in 2002 (then Education for All Fast Track Initiative, EFA FTI) with SEK 1,970,000,000. In December 2015 (overall, calculated from GPE's start in 2002), Sweden was the 7th largest contributor after the United Kingdom, the Netherlands, Australia, Norway, Spain and Denmark. Sweden's contribution to date amounts to 7.1% of the fund's total resources. Sida intends to contribute SEK 560,000,000 to GPE for the period 2016 - 2019.

Nya medel/medeltillägg för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 Utbildning är en mänsklig rättighet och nödvändigt för att kunna nyttja de andra mänskliga rättigheterna. Utbildning främjar frihet och egenmakt och bidrar till utveckling. Detta till trots, saknar miljontals barn, ungdomar och vuxna tillgång till utbildningsmöjligheter. Och för många är fattigdom den underliggande orsaken. Utbildning i fattiga länder är gravt underfinansierad. Beräkningar av UNESCO gör gällande att det behövs 39 miljarder dollar per år, utöver länders inhemska resurser, för att garantera alla barn en fullgod utbildning, från förskola till gymnasiet.
Global Partnership for Education, GPE, är ett partnerskap som etablerades 2002 i syfte att stödja fattiga länders utbildningsplaner för att nå förbättrade utbildningsresultat. I partnerskapet ingår nationella regeringar från mer än 60 låg- och medelinkomstländer, drygt 20 givarländer, multilaterala organisationer, enskilda organisationer och representanter för privata sektorn och stiftelser. En fond är kopplad till partnerskapet. Låg- och lägre medelinkomstländer med bristfälliga utbildningsresultat kan ansöka om stöd från GPE för att genomföra sina utbildningsplaner.
GPE:s övergripande mål är förbättrade utbildningsresultat för alla - flickor och pojkar, unga kvinnor och unga män - genom jämlik och jämställd tillgång till utbildning av god kvalité. Särskilt fokus läggs på de fattigaste och de som är mest marginaliserade till följd av kön, funktionsnedsättning, etnicitet, konflikt eller annan sårbarhet. GPE uppmärksammar även vikten av att lärarna har kapacitet och kunskap att undervisa på ett adekvat sätt samt att utbildningssystemen inklusive utbildningsplanerna är utformade för att effektivt förmedla fullgod och relevant utbildning.
Länder som är berättigade att ansöka om bidrag från GPE kan erhålla stöd för att antingen utveckla utbildningsplaner eller för att genomföra redan godkända planer. GPE har, sedan starten 2002, allokerat totalt 4,4 miljarder dollar till utbildning i världens fattigaste länder.
GPE styrs av en styrelse bestående av 19 medlemmar som representerar partnerskapets olika aktörer. I styrelsen finns sex givarvalkretsar, sex valkretsar som representerar samarbetsländerna, tre multilaterala organ (UNICEF, UNESCO och Världsbanken), tre representanter för civilsamhälleorganisationer och en för privata sektorn och stiftelser. Sverige och Danmark utgör en valkrets.
Sida bedömer att GPE har utvecklats mycket under sina 14 verksamhetsår. GPE skiljer sig från andra globala initiativ genom att arbetsmodellen bygger på tydligt nationellt ägarskap och jämlikt partnerskap mellan givare och samarbetsländer. GPE har rollen både som bidragsgivare, samordnare och som påverkansaktör för att öka förståelsen för utbildningens betydelse för hållbar utveckling.
Sverige har stött GPE sedan dess start 2002 (dåvarande Education for All Fast Track Initiative, EFA FTI)med 1 970 000 000 SEK. Sverige var i december 2015 (totalt sett, beräknat från GPE:s start 2002) den 7:de största bidragsgivaren efter Storbritannien, Nederländerna, Australien, Norge, Spanien och Danmark. Sveriges hittillsvarande bidrag uppgår till 7,1 % av fondens totala resurser. Sida avser bidra med 560 000 000 SEK till GPE för perioden 2016 - 2019.

participating-org.narrative: IBRD/International Bank for Reconstruction and Development/The World Bank

tag.narrative: 4.1 - By 2030, ensure that all girls and boys complete free, equitable and quality primary and secondary education leading to relevant and effective learning outcomes.
4.1 - Senast 2030 säkerställa att alla flickor och pojkar fullbordar avgiftsfri och likvärdig grundskole- och gymnasieutbildning av god kvalitet som leder till relevanta och ändamålsenliga kunskaper.
4.2 - By 2030, ensure that all girls and boys have access to quality early childhood development, care and pre-primary education so that they are ready for primary education.
4.2 - Senast 2030 säkerställa att alla flickor och pojkar har tillgång till förskola av god kvalitet som ger omvårdnad och förbereder dem för att börja grundskolan.

4.5 - By 2030, eliminate gender disparities in education and ensure equal access to all levels of education and vocational training for the vulnerable, including persons with disabilities, indigenous peoples and children in vulnerable situations.

4.5 - Senast 2030 avskaffa skillnaderna mellan könen inom utbildningsområdet och säkerställa lika tillgång till utbildning och yrkesutbildning på alla nivåer för utsatta personer, inklusive personer med funktionsnedsättning, ursprungsfolk och barn som lever under utsatta förhållanden.
4.6 - By 2030, ensure that all youth and a substantial proportion of adults, both men and women, achieve literacy and numeracy.
4.6 - Senast 2030 säkerställa att alla ungdomar och en väsentlig andel av alla vuxna – både män och kvinnor – lär sig läsa, skriva och räkna.
4.a - Build and upgrade education facilities that are child, disability and gender sensitive and provide safe, non-violent, inclusive and effective learning environments for all.

4.a - Bygga och förbättra utbildningsmiljöer som är anpassade för barn och personer med funktionsnedsättning, samt tar hänsyn till jämställdhetsaspekter och därmed erbjuder en trygg, fredlig, inkluderande och ändamålsenlig lärandemiljö för alla.

4.c - By 2030, substantially increase the supply of qualified teachers, including through international cooperation for teacher training in developing countries, especially least developed countries and small island developing States.

4.c - Till 2030 väsentligen öka tillgången på utbildade lärare, bland annat genom internationellt samarbete kring lärarutbildning i utvecklingsländerna, särskilt de minst utvecklade länderna och små önationer under utveckling.

title.narrative: Beslut om ändring av insats GPE dec 2020

description.narrative: Since 2002, GPE has distributed close to 5 billion USD in support of national education plan implementation in over 60 developing countries. About 50% of the GPE funding supports education in fragile and conflict-affected countries. The partnership has grown from seven developingcountry partners (DCPs) in 2002 to 65 Almost all of these are low-income countries, home to 330 million children— of which 79 million are out of school. The numberof DCPs is expected to grow to 89 over the next three years. The number of countries providing funding for the GPE grew from fewer than 10 in 2004 to more than 20 by 2018. The number of children supported by GPE surpassed the2017 reached 23,5 million in 2019. 76.1% of children completed primary education 50.2% of children completed lower secondary education. 37.2% of children enrolled in pre-primary education. There has been good progress in gender equity in primary and secondary education. 66% of DCPs were within threshold for gender parity index for primary completion, 51% of DCPs were within threshold for gender parity index for lower secondary completion. Gender parity is still a challenge however , especially for out of school chidren. Primary-school-age girls were 1.3 times more likely than boys to be out of school. The gender equality strategy, which was adopted in 2017, is expected to address gender equality. Data is often not available to assess to what extent learning is improving. Only one third of developing country partners (20 countries) had reliable learning data. Of these, 13 countries (65 percent) show improved learning outcomes. Teacher density, a prerequisite for improved learning, shows a positive trend. 29 percent of partner countries in developing countries had the number of students in a qualified teacher at or below 40: 1, compared to 25 percent in 2013. But in many countries, it is still very high. The Better Early Learning and Development at Scale initiative (BELDS) supports improved capacity for qualitative early learning planning.GPE publishes detailed results reports annually starting in 2017 and available on its website.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

strategy.title: Global strategy on socially sustainable development 2018-2022
strategy.titleSV: Global strategi för socialt hållbar utveckling 2018-2022

description.narrative:
Det föreslagna programmet har som målsättning att uppnå en god styrning av skogsbruket i utvecklingsländer samt att främja legal handel med skogsprodukter. Detta förväntas även på lång sikt bidra till en hållbar skogsanvändning och fattigdomsbekämpning. FAO FLEGT är ett stödprogram till EU FLEGT, för att bygga kunskap och kapacitet på policy- såväl som på företags- och samhällsnivå för att länder ska kunna ingå i ”voluntary partnership agreements” (VPA) förhandlingar och/eller för att kunna förbereda och verkställa initiativ för hållbart skogsbruk utanför VPA ramverket. Det är en utveckling av tidigare fas av samma program men med ett större fokus på små och medium-stora företag och deras möjlighet att påverka och delta i förhandlingar om skogslagstiftning och legal handel. Sidas bedömning är att insatsen har potential till att bidra till ett mer hållbart skogsbruk (miljömässigt, socialt och ekonomiskt) och till att de potentiella fördelarna med legal handel av timmer och handelsavtal för ett hållbart skogsbruk även gagnar småbrukare och har potential att hjälpa människor ur fattigdom.
Programmets totala budget är 45,000,000 USD (ca 332,300,000 SEK) av vilket FAO själv kommer att bidra med 10% av Sidas och ECs bidrag. EC har initialt gått in med 13,000,000 EUR men förväntas öka sitt bidrag i takt med att programmet implementeras. Cirka hälften av budgeten kommer att vidareförmedlas i form av grants genom en direkt stöd mekanism och årliga ”call for proposals” i de aktuella länderna (15 VPA länder och 10 icke-VPA länder).
Initiativet styrs och genomförs av FAO som har stor teknisk kunskap i området samt lång erfarenhet av liknande initiativ till exempel National Forest Program Facility (NFP) och Forest and Farm Facility (FFF). Sida stödjer redan FFF initiativet med ett kärnstöd över fem år och FLEGT Facility regionalt (Asien). Det finns goda möjligheter till synergier mellan de tre programmen och Sida, i sin roll som betydande givare till båda, har möjligheten att bidra till utvecklingen mot ett globalt hållbart skogsbruk.

The FLEGT (Forest Law Enforcement, Governance and Trade) initiative aims to exclude illegal timber from the markets, to improve the supply of legal timber and to increase the demand for responsible wood products. The initiative will lead to a positive impact, economic as well as social, in the areas of intervention.

General This Conclusion on Performance is based upon FAO FLEGT’s Annual Report 2020 with Annexes, follow-up discussions, peer learning meetings (virtual), and additional reporting materials submitted by the FLEGT team to Sida (upon request). The ANR 2020 submitted by FAO-FLEGT consists in one main report and six annexes, namely: Annex 1: Summary of programme intervention in VPA and non-VPA countries during 2020; Annex 2: Report against programme log-frame indicators; Annex 3: Work plan 2021 Programme-level activities; Annex 4: FAO EU-FLEGT Programme involvement in significant regional/global events related to FLEGT: 2021; Annex 5: Invitation and Agenda for the 18th Steering Committee meeting; Annex 6: Minutes of the 17th Steering Committee Meeting. Objectives of the intervention The FLEGT (Forest Law Enforcement, Governance and Trade) initiative aims to exclude illegal timber from the markets, to improve the supply of legal timber and to increase the demand for responsible wood products. It is expected that the programme should lead to a positive impact, economic as well as social, in the areas of intervention. Intervention logic for the programme: There are 6 set outcomes and 1 cross-cutting area that is set in order to achieve the set objective of the programme, and these are presented below. Outcome 1: Support for countries engaged in voluntary partnership agreements (VPA). VPAs contribute to improved forest sector governance and timber legality on domestic and international markets. Since Phase III began in January 2016, 73 percent of all projects endorsed for funding has been in VPA countries. In combination with global and regional projects that also primarily addressed VPA countries, 82.4 percent of the budget for projects (20 million USD) has been dedicated to VPA countries. Of these, 108 projects were selected through the Direct Assistance mechanism and 155 through the Call for Proposals mechanism. The VPA countries covered by the programme are Cameroon, CAR, Congo, Côte d’Ivoire, DRC, Gabon, Ghana, Liberia, Indonesia, Laos, Malaysia, Thailand, Viet Nam, Guyana and Honduras. Outcome 2: Support for countries not engaged in voluntary partnership agreements (VPA). Initiatives that support legal production and consumption of timber and better forest sector governance in countries that are not engaged in the VPA process are strengthened. In other words, this outcome covers progress related to non-VPA countries. Since Phase III began in January 2016, 24 percent of all projects endorsed for funding has been in non-VPA countries, accounting for 17.6 percent of the budget for projects (4.8 million USD). Of all the projects launched in non-VPA countries to date, 79 projects were selected through the Direct Assistance mechanism and 7 through the Call for Proposals mechanism. The non-VPA countries covered by the programme are Colombia, Guatemala, Madagascar, Mozambique, Myanmar, Peru, the Philippines, Benin, Panama and Papua New Guinea. Outcome 3: Private sector support. The capacity of the private sector (particularly MSMEs) to participate in the trade of legal timber has increased. This outcome especially reports on the programmes’ support to private sector development. During the reporting period, the Programme maintained strong support to private sector, primarily targeting MSMEs. Besides building capacity for legality compliance, the Programme supported the uptake of digital tools and platforms demonstrating legal production and facilitating access to legal markets. In 2020, the Programme launched an internal review of Phase III support to MSMEs and gathered preliminary lessons which will provide technical knowledge to scale up support in the wake of the COVID-19 pandemic. Outcome 4: Outreach and knowledge sharing. Stakeholders in both consumer and producer countries demonstrate an improved knowledge of benefits from legal logging, international trade requirements and of best practices for forest law enforcement, governance and trade. Throughout 2020, the Programme supported both country-level communication emerging from projects and programme-level outreach. The Programme also contributed to corporate communication needs emerging from the COVID-19 crisis, namely through the organization of targeted events and the production of thematic policy briefs. Outcome 5: VPA Impact Monitoring. Programme support to VPA impact monitoring has generated results, particularly in Africa and Asia, during the reporting period. One result from this outcome is presented below. Outcome 6: Capacity building and partnerships. In 2020, 35 implementing partners (from VPA and non-VPA countries in all three regions) were requested to undergo the Programme Due Diligence checks, providing more insight into their institutional background, before introducing Programme requirements and receiving training on project management. The process originally applied only to new partners, but has now been extended to all non-governmental actors starting new projects with the Programme, and governmental actors with no prior experience with the Programme. Key area of integration: Gender equality and women’s empowerment in small forest enterprises. Gender mainstreaming is at the core of numerous initiatives across different countries supported by the Programme. During Phase III, the Programme has significantly increased the focus on gender equality in forest governance and legal timber value chains, and the significant increase in demand for support to include gender considerations in partner activities since 2019 reflects this trend. There is an additional result area presented in the report, called “Impact of trade and governance”. It is not reported as an outcome, rather integrated throughout the outcomes, but it is possible to track how much of the programmes’ funding that is linked to trade and governance. In 2020, approximately 3% of the total funding went to this result area, and a slight increase compared to 2019 (2%).

title.narrative: 14/000817 Amendment 1 to the Agreement between Sida and FAO FLEGT 2015-2019
14/000817 Amendment 2 to the Agreement between Sida and FAO FLEGT 2015-2021

14/000817 Beslut om avtalsändring för insats FAO FLEGT 2015-2019
14/000817 Beslut om avtalsändring för insats FAO FLEGT 2015-2021

description.narrative: This Sida contribution contributes to different levels, i.e. global/normative level [GLOB/NORM], at national/institutional level [NAT/INST] and actors/target group [ACT/TG] of the Theory of Change (ToC) of the Strategy for Sweden’s global development cooperation in sustainable economic development 2018-2022. Indeed, it contributes to five of its strategic objectives: 1.1 – Free and equitable trade; 2.1 – Strengthened ownership and tenure rights for land and natural resources; 2.2 – Improved conditions for private sector development, sustainable business and responsible and sustainable investments and innovations; 2.3 – Increased productivity and sustainable production in agriculture, forestry and fisheries, including food security; and 2.4 – Strengthened women's economic empowerment. The target group of the programme, the smallholder forestry farmers, are directly involved in the programme for some of the outcomes (e.g. outcome 3) and indirectly impacted for others (e.g. outcome 4). The FAO FLEGT Programme reports results based on 4 outcomes and selected cross-cutting areas (gender equality and youth). These results also show a connection to GLOBECs objectives, as well as GLOBECs ToC (or how they “channel” change). Results from the FAO FLEGT Programme Example 1 [Outcome 1 – Legal compliance, market access and livelihoods]: In all VPA countries, even where the VPA mechanism itself is stalled as a result of the Covid-19 effects, programme support strengthening the demand for legal timber in the domestic market and MSME compliance along the timber value chain has been instrumental in building opportunities for long-term livelihood generation and sustainable forest resource use. In Cameroon, companies were linked with community forest timber producers and concluded transactions for an approximate 15 000 cubic meters of legal timber [NAT/ INST] [TG/ACT]. In Indonesia, Programme support to private sector associations and NGOs contributed to improved SVLK (Sistem Verifikasi Legalitas Kayu – Timber Legality Assurance System) uptake by supporting legal harvesting, processing and trade by over 400 smallholder timber producers and MSMEs. Support towards alternate timber trading methods, such as the use of e-commerce platforms, has been particularly important for smallholders to ensure business continuity during the pandemic [NAT/ INST] [TG/ACT]. On an outcome level, support through technical assistance and training (such as improved governance systems), empowers that target groups to access local and national markets, fair and equitable trade, improve their livelihoods and thus indirectly contributes to poverty alleviation. This has also allowed the smallholder farmers to better cope with shifting market demands and the impacts of climate change, such as droughts and floods. The result under this outcome reports to several of the tagged objectives under GLOBEC’s strategy, i.e. 1.1, 2.1, 2.2 and 2.3. Example 2 [Outcome 1 – Strengthening the role of communities in forest management]: In Guyana, Programme partners developed training manuals for indigenous communities with guidelines on employment, social security, income tax, forest management and environmental requirements to comply with the Guyana Timber Legality Assurance System (GTLAS) [NAT/INST] [TG/ACT]. This in turn, supports the smallholder forest farmers to build resilience of social-ecological systems and for livelihoods strengthening. This example contributes to objective 2.1, 2.2 and 2.3 of GLOBEN’s strategy. Moreover, the examples above elucidates the reader upon the importance of working around institutions’ and organisations’ strengthening, with an emphasis on civil society and collective action, by using an ‘improved livelihoods and sustainable economic development approach’. VPA processes can are often lengthy processes, where the different countries are at different levels of progress towards FLEGT licenses. One of the many main lessons learned, also as emphasised by FLEGT in the ANR, is that during extensive processes, stakeholder can still be kept engaged by supporting the development and roll-out of the building blocks of the VPA. One way of doing this, is to work with institutions’ strengthening and coordination, empowering smallholder forestry farmers in the set up on MSMEs, and by building alliances with likeminded organisations and/or programmes’ such as the Forest and Farm Facility (FFF). Example 3 [Outcome 2 – Multi-stakeholder platforms]: In Myanmar, Programme support strengthened the country’s multi-stakeholder FLEGT platform by organizing the first-ever meetings of the 15 State and Regional-level Multi-Stakeholder Groups where 569 stakeholders provided 1,240 suggested activities for inclusion in the FAO-EU FLEGT Work Programme. These were conducted through remote means, representing a significant change in communication and collaboration among stakeholders, successfully demonstrating that remote consultation is possible [NAT/INST] [TG/ ACT]. This positive experience is being used by the Programme to support partners in other countries where there is a need to replicate such remote consultation [GLOB/ NORM]. This example results essentially reports to 2.1, 2.2 and 2.3. Example 4 [Outcome 2 – Legal and policy reform and Gender Equality]: In Uganda, the Programme support in 2020 launched a project to develop a gender mainstreaming manual for forest policy to be adopted by the Ugandan Forestry Authorities. This work will create a new approach to engaging women in the forest sector and generating benefits for women, through gender-appropriate material and methods which target women and address their specific needs [NAT/INST] [TG/ACT]. This result can be tied to the following objectives for respective strategy: 2.1; 2.2; 2.3; and 2.4. This result explicitly reports to the policy marker on gender equality (marked as significant). Example 5 [Outcome 2 – Strengthening the role of communities in forest management]: In Peru, lessons learned were gathered from efforts to strengthen the organization and structures for indigenous communities’ forest oversight in two regions (Atalaya and San Martin). It was found that the “Veedurías Forestales” of Peru are most effective when considered a system of implementing community control over their entire territories, rather than specific forest monitoring tools. While these community systems and structures have been well developed on paper, many still show inconsistencies in their operations and are vulnerable to conflict of interests, despite their impartiality and independence from the Government. These lessons learned now enable the Programme to offer concrete recommendations for future strengthening the role of indigenous communities in Peru regarding forest oversight [NAT/INST] [TG/ACT]. The latest example clearly emphasises on the importance of the presence of the programme in non-VPA countries, critical in capacity building, organisational development, and for creating a momentum around sustainable forest management, legal timber production, market demand, and empowerment of IPLCs. This example reports to objective 2.1 and 2.3 of the strategy. Example 6 – [Gender Equality integration]: The Programme increased efforts in gender mainstreaming. A total of 48 percent of the projects endorsed from the 2019 Calls for Proposal placed a strong emphasis on strengthening gender mainstreaming by including gender as a key component, whilst 30 percent of the projects focusing on MSMEs support included gender components [GLOB/NORM]. Gender mainstreaming is at the core of numerous initiatives across different countries supported by the Programme. Since 2017, The Programme has assisted Indonesian CSOs to reinforce Independent Forest Monitoring (IFM) by training and empowering traditionally underrepresented groups such as women and youth. Recognizing this, in 2020, Programme partners provided targeted workshops for more than 78 women across the islands of Java, Sumatra, South Sulawesi and Kalimantan, equipping them with the necessary skills to prepare monitoring plans, conduct IFM and report to relevant authorities [NAT/INST] [TG/ACT]. This result can be tied to the following objectives for respective strategy: 2.1; 2.2; 2.3; and 2.4. As for example 4, this result explicitly reports to the policy marker on gender equality (marked as significant). Example 7 [Global contribution of FLEGT-related work to the broader forestry and development agenda]: FAO recognizes that protecting forests is a solution common to multiple development agendas, as part of nature-based solutions to mitigating the effects of climate change, halting deforestation, enabling green growth and preventing further biodiversity loss. For example, in 2020, the Programme contributed to advancing the biodiversity conservation agenda through a series of actions aligned with the Operating Principles of FAO’s Strategy on Mainstreaming Biodiversity Across Agricultural Sectors. By addressing forest degradation caused by illegal logging and overharvesting, the implementation of FLEGT-related interventions promotes Sustainable Forest Management (SFM) through improved law enforcement and governance, thereby protecting forest-dependant livelihoods. SFM is recognized as an important measure to address climate change mitigation and adaptation in agriculture and land-use sectors and comprises a key element of the NDC plans for many countries, as shown in a recent analysis of NDCs in Asia [GLOB/NORM] [ACT/TG]. Reported results can be connected to the following strategic objectives: 2.1; 2.2; and 2.3.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

Det föreslagna programmet har som målsättning att uppnå en god styrning av skogsbruket i utvecklingsländer samt att främja legal handel med skogsprodukter. Detta förväntas även på lång sikt bidra till en hållbar skogsanvändning och fattigdomsbekämpning. FAO FLEGT är ett stödprogram till EU FLEGT, för att bygga kunskap och kapacitet på policy- såväl som på företags- och samhällsnivå för att länder ska kunna ingå i ”voluntary partnership agreements” (VPA) förhandlingar och/eller för att kunna förbereda och verkställa initiativ för hållbart skogsbruk utanför VPA ramverket. Det är en utveckling av tidigare fas av samma program men med ett större fokus på små och medium-stora företag och deras möjlighet att påverka och delta i förhandlingar om skogslagstiftning och legal handel. Sidas bedömning är att insatsen har potential till att bidra till ett mer hållbart skogsbruk (miljömässigt, socialt och ekonomiskt) och till att de potentiella fördelarna med legal handel av timmer och handelsavtal för ett hållbart skogsbruk även gagnar småbrukare och har potential att hjälpa människor ur fattigdom.
Programmets totala budget är 45,000,000 USD (ca 332,300,000 SEK) av vilket FAO själv kommer att bidra med 10% av Sidas och ECs bidrag. EC har initialt gått in med 13,000,000 EUR men förväntas öka sitt bidrag i takt med att programmet implementeras. Cirka hälften av budgeten kommer att vidareförmedlas i form av grants genom en direkt stöd mekanism och årliga ”call for proposals” i de aktuella länderna (15 VPA länder och 10 icke-VPA länder).
Initiativet styrs och genomförs av FAO som har stor teknisk kunskap i området samt lång erfarenhet av liknande initiativ till exempel National Forest Program Facility (NFP) och Forest and Farm Facility (FFF). Sida stödjer redan FFF initiativet med ett kärnstöd över fem år och FLEGT Facility regionalt (Asien). Det finns goda möjligheter till synergier mellan de tre programmen och Sida, i sin roll som betydande givare till båda, har möjligheten att bidra till utvecklingen mot ett globalt hållbart skogsbruk.
